I am at a loss to understand how the body responsible for the application of, the decision-making of, quarantine restriction measures in this country got it so terribly wrong. It has been implied by the Prime Minister that this is about trade, but this is not a trade issue. The 75 restrictions were put in place not to protect the salmon industry of Tasmaniaâor anywhere else, albeit it principally operates in Tasmaniaâbecause it did not exist then. They were put in place to protect the recreational trout fisheries of this country, which has applica tion in a number of states, not just Tasmania. That is why they were put in place.

So we proceed to look at the problems associated with the diseases. We are told by the WTO, using an agreement and aspects of the sanitary and phyto-sanitary agreement that we were the principal architects of, that we must conduct a comprehensive risk analysis. They give us a very short period of time to do it. In this instance it does not have application only to wild, ocean-caught Pacific salmon. It has application to all salmonid product from anywhere in the world. So we conduct that risk analysis.

One very important disease is included in the process, the disease known as infectious salmon anaemia. It has been found in Norway since 1984. It has spread throughout northern Europe and into Canada and maybe in parts of the US. There is some scientific opinion as to how it is spread, but there is no conclusive proof. There is also scientific opinion that the disease spread as a result of trade in fish product. That is a fact. I find it amazing that there is no clinical test available to identify infected fish, unless they show clinical signs of infectionâthat is, they have blotches and appear very sick. At this point in time, unless the fish show signs of the disease and can be visibly identified to have it, no other test is available to identify which infected fish have the disease.

I am quite amazed that we failed to argue this case very strongly. The general public of Australia should know that in Norway nowadays salmon farming is very significant, in Australia it is very small. We represent just a drop in the ocean in respect of salmon farming in the world. But in Norway salmon farming is a big industry and a very powerful lobbier of government. When Norway gets an outbreak of infectious salmon anaemia in any of the waterways, what do they do? They use a poison called rotenol and they poison the rivers and waterways, no matter how big, and they kill everything. They do that for at least three years.

As someone who has a recreational interest in fishing, I know that if you go to Norway, the only fish you can catch nowadays are those that are released by farms. You cannot catch any wild fish because they have basically wiped them out. The same thing is happening elsewhere.

We know that there is a major problem in net caged salmon farming in many parts of the world with regard to wild fish stocks. We know that it has been scientifically proven that wild fish stocks are declining at such a rate that it is likely that in most of the northern hemisphere wild salmonids will not exist in the next 10 to 15 years.

In Canada, the wild Atlantic salmon stocks have reached such a levelâthis is what I find very interestingâthat the United Nations has taken steps to stop commercial fishing of wild Atlantic salmon. That means no commercial fishing. In places like Newfoundland there is no commercial fishing. The United Nations knew that if it did not take those steps the genetics of wild Atlantic salmon could not continue. In fact, it believes at the moment that it is highly likely that there are sufficient stocks for them to continue.

I say to the government and to AQIS, who have bungled this monumentally, that they have an opportunity to right the wrong. They should do it and, most of all, they should not threaten the state that is actually trying to do the right thing. Tasmania should be joined by other state Premiers in fighting this battle because right now the Commonwealth is incapable of doing so on the basis that it has no interest in the fresh water environs of this country. I suggest to the government that they listen long and hard about that. (Time expired)
Sitting suspended from 1.44 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity of representing the minister for health. Is the minister aware that the minister for health has publicly asserted that he has acted quickly in responding to concerns about the MRI scandal, despite being warned on 5 May 1998 by the department that there may be a problem, being told in August 1998 by the department that there was a problem and the concerns raised publicly by Labor since February 1999? Can the minister explain why the minister for health acted to close off applications for eligible MRI machines only in October 1999, some 18 months after first being warned of the problem? Why did the minister for health then express astonishment that radiologists were still submitting applications, when he left open that massive window of opportunity for them? If it takes 18 months for the minister for health to act quickly in responding to concerns, how does he react slowly?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âMadam President, you can always count on the Labor Party for one thing: the conspiracy theory. As I said yesterday, the minister has answered questions in the other chamber. There were questions asked in the estimates committee as well and those matters have been raised in the other chamber. He has provided detailed answers to those matters and has made a number of statements on the public record. If there is anything further that needs to be added to that, I am happy to get back to Senator Evans with an answer from the minister.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister would be aware that I asked these questions at estimates some months ago, because he was at the table at the time. But I asked a very specific question which I think the parliament deserves an answer to, and that is: why did the minister for health take 18 months to close off applications for eligible MRI machines when concerns were raised with him by the department in May 1998? They were supposed to have signed the contract by then. Why did he wait 18 months before he closed off their ability to claim for that eligibility?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âSenator Evans's estimate is that it was 18 months. The minister took appropriate action. As Senator Evans would recall, at the Senate estimates committee there was discussion of this matter and there were investigations proceeding. Undertakings were given at that time that certain information should not be divulged because it may prejudice those investigations. If there is anything further that the minister wishes me to give to Senator Evans, I am happy to approach him about that.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. The minister will be aware of the need for an open, honest and accountable approach to policy formulation. Will the minister inform the Senate of the government's approach to the privatisation of government assets? Is he aware of any alternative policy approaches and can he inform the Senate of the impact if these approaches were adopted?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âIt is a very important question that Senator Parer asks because it really goes to the heart of the approach that ought to be adopted by all political parties in this country, and that is openness and transparency in policy formulation and policy statement. We have always been up-front about our intentions in relation to Telstra and I think the public have respected us for that. We made it clear, we took the risks, we accepted that there were significant segments of the population who either were opposed to it or had been persuaded that they should be opposed to it. Nonetheless, we were able to demonstrate that there were very significant benefits that would flow, not just in terms of reducing public sector debt but in ensuring that the money was used for sensible capital works programs. And, of course, the billion dollar social bonus package that we took to the last election I think went a long way towards alleviating a lot of concerns in rural areas about the quality of telecommunications services.

answer.para: What I suppose really sticks in the craw of all those who are interested in this debate is that, when in government, you had Mr Beazleyânow the Leader of the Opposition but at various stages in a crucial position to affect privatisationâbeing the great privatiser himself. He was the finance minister when the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas were sold off, after, of course, the government had given an ironclad guarantee that they would notâthat they had no intention whatever toâfurther reduce their shareholding. Mr Beazley, in factâas we all knowâwent to the Press Club and trenchantly justified the whole notion of privatisation. He said it did not result in a loss of infrastructure; it was merely a transfer of ownershipâand, of course, he has argued the case long and hard in government.

What do we now find? Of course, he is the strongest opponent of privatisation. Why? Obviously for purely tactical reasons, and yet again today we have him being exposed by Mr Blount, the former CEO of Telstra, saying yesterday that a senior Hawke government minister had told him that the Labor Party were committed to privatisation. He said he was told about the plan during a confidential meeting before his appointment to head Telstra was known. In other words, the only reason he came out here was that he was on a promise. What happened, of course, was that he was well and truly conned: he was brought out here under false pretences because they reneged on the deal.

Who was involved in that? Who made that promise? We know one thing for sure: Mr Beazley was the minister for communications at the time. And what Mr Blount says is that the whole purpose of his trip was to see if it was really doable to be the CEO of a company owned 100 per cent by the government; it was all about trying to explore this with the government and with the minister of the day. Well, who was the minister of the day? So it is quite clear that Mr Beazley has a lot of explaining to do. He has put out a statement today saying:
I have never suggested to Mr Blount that I was in favour of Telstra privatisation, and Mr Blount said that I had made no such suggestion to him.

The alternative explanation is that he was actually present when other ministers argued in favour of privatisation but, unfortunately, he did not quite have the ticker to express a private reservation. That is highly unlikely, I have to say, because he privatised everything else he could get his hands on. Let us just assume that, for some reason, he did not quite want to go that farâmainly because the unions would not let him and all of the rest. So he just sat there quietly. He let Mr Blount believe that the Labor Party was in favour of privatisation and that they did want to see Telstra in private hands. He said nothing. That is the alternative explanation.

It is a very tragic state of affairs that you cannot have someone come clean on one of the biggest policy issues of the momentâin fact, of the decade. Mr Beazley's weasel words on this subject do him no credit at all. It ought to be clear to anyone who looks at what Mr Blount has had to say that he does not contradict Mr Beazley. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Health and Aged Care: Fundraising

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Ellison, the Special Minister of State. Is the minister aware of yesterday's confirmation by the Minister for Health and Aged Care that certain radiologists who have profited from the MRI Medicare rebate have attended fundraising functions for Dr Wooldridge? Given that it is Dr Wooldridge himself who claims that these donations have been properly disclosed, has the minister satisfied himself that this is in fact the case?

âMadam President, I am not aware of the details of the question or answer given yesterday in relation to the question that Senator Faulkner raises. I would need to have a look at that and get back to Senator Faulkner. But can I say that, from what I have seen, there has been nothing untoward at all in what Minister Wooldridge has said. In fact, I think he has acted quite honourably in this whole matter. He has taken this whole matter on theâ
âYou are getting yourself into quicksand with this.

âI hear Senator Schacht interjecting. He could take a leaf or two out of the minister for health's book in the way he has handled this matter. He has referred this to the National Audit Office and is not shying away from any investigation into this matter. In fact, he has been proactive in sorting the matter out. In that way he has acted entirely appropriately.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer again to Dr Wooldridge's statement that, `Any money that has been raised has been properly disclosed.' I ask the minister, given that he is responsible for the law governing election campaign disclosures, why he has not satisfied himself that Dr Wooldridge was correct in this statement. I am surprised that the minister is not aware of the statement. But if he has not satisfied himself and he is not aware of the statement, which I think most senators and the public would find extraordinary, will he undertake to do so nowâhe has indicated he willâas a matter of urgency and report back to the Senate before we rise tonight?

âMadam President, I will treat Senator Faulkner's request as I do any other request that I receive in relation to matters under the Electoral Act and deal with them in an appropriate manner. If there is anything to be brought back to the Senate, then I will.

âMadam President, my question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate how the government's reform of business taxation will encourage higher investment and greater productivity in the Australian economy?

âThank you, Senator Chapman, for that very important question. The government's reform of business taxation is designed to encourage business investment, to create jobs and to strengthen Australia's economic potential. I would like to take this opportunity to inform the Senate about a statement made by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry released earlier this week regarding the Ralph report. This is what the chamber said:

answer.para: Reforming business taxation to make Australia more internationally competitive, more attractive to foreign capital inflow and more rewarding to investment and innovation must be seen as one of Australia's highest priorities. The Ralph report has provided this country with a blueprint for business tax reform which has the overwhelming support of the business community.

It is clear that there is overwhelming support for the Ralph report, support that extends from accountants to the Institute of Company Directors, the National Farmers Federation and the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. There is broad support for a package that fundamentally improves the structure of business tax laws in this country.

talk.start.para: âNot too much support among the poor, though.

âThese reforms will provide greater certainty for business and make the system simpler, particularly for small business. Senator Murphy calls out but my understanding is that the Labor Party admittedly flip-flops on this as on so many other issues. If you read the general thrust of the shadow Treasurer's comments, he is purporting to be broadly supportive of these reforms. If that is the caseâif that is trueâwe welcome that.

answer.para: In a revenue neutral manner, these reforms will cut the tax rate for companies and make Australia internationally competitive through lower capital gains tax rates. Let me remind the Senateâand I think this is a very important figureâthat 77 per cent of taxpayers paying capital gains tax earn under $50,000. Our proposal to cut capital gains tax and introduce rollover relief for scrip for scrip takeovers is very important and will be welcomed by all taxpayers.

The Ralph report recommendations will also give Australia a company tax rate that is internationally competitive. At 30 per cent it is lower than in Canada, Japan, the US and many other of our trading partners. It is clear that the Australian economy will be further improved by the reforms that we are bringing down.

It was very pleasing today to see the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index, which surveys the Australian economy. It showed a 5.7 per cent growth in August compared with an average growth rate over the last six months of 5.6 per cent. While we treat all figures with some caution, these particular figures are certainly encouraging and show that this government is on track, with a strong reform agenda to further improve the competitiveness of the Australian economy and to create jobs.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the supply-side arrangements for Medicare eligibility for MRI machines were just one side of an agreement between the government and radiologists? Isn't it true that, prior to the 1998 budget, radiologists signed up to an agreement that capped the expenditure on radiology? talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Forshaw for the question. The principle of capping was the same as that of the Labor Party's in relation to pathology services, so to imply there is some conspiracy in relation to capping is a criticism of the Labor Party itself. That principle was the same as the one applied to MRI scanning. Obviously I am not aware of the dates that Senator Forshaw has put to the Senate. I will check with the minister to see whether those dates are correct, and I will also check what occurred at the meeting that Senator Forshaw referred to.

answer.para: The important thing is that the action of the government means that MRI scanning has become available to a much larger number of Australians. It is a technology that has been late in coming to Australia. It was the principal type of technology in relation to image scanning in the US. MRI scanning as a part of imaging is four per cent of the total cost of medical imaging in this country. Even though it is only four per cent of the total medical imaging costs, it is important that the government protects taxpayers' money, and that is what it is doing. If I can supply any further information to Senator Forshaw in relation to the question, I will get back to him.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Women's Representation on Advisory Committees

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Newman, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Can the minister inform the Senate what representation women have on the Howard government's advisory committees on the GST?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I do not think that is a very helpful question. I do not know which committees she is particularly referring to. I myself am a member of about four committees at cabinet level that are involved in an advisory position to the implementation groups, but I am afraid she will need to be more specific. Which committees were you referring to, Senator?

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you provide to the Senate information about the role the Office of the Status of Women has played in ensuring that women are represented on the committees, in accord with the government's goal of equal representation on public committees?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe senator suggests that she is talking about public committees. She still has not been specific and I cannot inform her adequately if I do not know which committees she is talking about.

âMy question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. In relation to yesterday's rally of 3,000 people in Albury protesting against the inadequate flow of water in the Snowy River, and in recognition of the policy of the Snowy River Alliance to restore 28 per cent of the original flow to the Snowy River, will the minister assure the Senate that he will work with the state governments concerned to obtain a fairer allocation of water, taking into account the needs of irrigators and pastoralists and the environmental necessity to increase the flow of water in the Snowy River?

âI thank Senator Harris for that question. As I am sure Senator Harris knows, under our great federation the states have primary responsibility for management of our most precious resourceâwater. In relation to the Murray River, New South Wales, regrettably, manages its water resources so that only a minimum water reserve is carried over into the following year. This is a significant contrast to the state of Victoria, which keeps much more significant volumes of water in reserve for the following season. The fact is that Victorian farmers, therefore, do have a higher level of water security than those in New South Wales. I do think that the New South Wales government does need to come to grips with this issue of effective water management in order to give its own farmers much more water security.

answer.para: New South Wales farmers who rely on the Murray have been experiencing considerable difficulty. There have been drought conditions and they have experienced, regrettably, the failure of the New South Wales government to give them proper water security. The New South Wales government approached the Snowy Mountains Council seeking access to additional water releases. We are, with Victoria and New South Wales, members of that council. I certainly passed on to the Commonwealth representatives on that council, for whom I have responsibility, that I wanted to see a speedy and satisfactory resolution of this. Certainly, my office was in close contact with the office of the then Victorian Premier to ensure that Victoria cooperated fully in this matter, and indeed Victoria did cooperate in ensuring that we got an outcome. The outcome was that, at the Snowy Mountains Council meeting last week, the council agreed to the New South Wales government's request, on behalf of the irrigators, that 300 gigalitres of additional water be made available.

I think it is important to remember in the face of the protests from the irrigators that have been going on that the scheme is already committed to supplying some 2,000 gigalitres to the irrigators, which I am advised is the equivalent of four times the volume of Sydney Harbour, and that there is no charge from the Snowy Mountains Council for that release. What is being asked for is water in addition to what is already a very significant allocation from the Snowy Mountains Scheme. What the council is doing is allowing the irrigators to bring forward a portion of next year's allocation to supplement this year's allocation. That is something we support. It is being provided on a quasi-commercial basis and it is in accord with the New South Wales government's request. As I say, and I want to stress, this has been brought about by the inadequacies of the New South Wales government's management of its water resources. It has sought a solution through the release, or the insurance provided by the guarantee of a release, of water from the Snowy scheme. We have responded positively to that.

We have supported the New South Wales government's request that water be supplied on that basis, and I am pleased to say it will be. The farmers, of course, are saying that it ought to be provided for free; that was not the original request and it certainly was not the New South Wales government's proposition that it put to the council. We supported the proposition put by the New South Wales government. The water is being provided at rates which I understand are at actually half the rate, half the price, originally proposed. So it is not free, but it is being provided at well below real cost.

talk.start.para: âThank you, Senator. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. At the rally yesterday it was clearly indicated that the problem was partly caused by an unusual release of 900,000 megalitres from the Hume Dam and that for the last three years the Snowy Mountains Scheme has each year reduced its output by 200,000 megalitres. Both of those instances now leave the pastoralists and the rice growers in New South Wales receiving only 11 per cent of their allocation. They cannot put in their crops and they cannot provide for their families. Would the minister in his official position consider making an allocation to replace those two volumes of water for those farmers?

âAs I say, the responsibility for water management for the New South Wales farmers is a matter for the New South Wales government. I have no direct authority. The matter of releases from the Snowy Mountains Scheme is a matter for the Snowy Mountains Council, on which the Commonwealth has two of the six governmental representatives. The council was approached for this, in effect, insurance scheme by way of a guarantee of 300 gigalitres to be made available if required so that the farmers would be able to plant now, knowing that that water will be available if they need it. We hope they will not need it; we hope there will be sufficient rain so that they will not need it. We have responded positively to that. We are in accord with the New South Wales government. What was sought by the farmers has been guaranteed, albeit that they sought it for free; it will not be for free but at a cost way below the real cost.

subdebateinfo.title: Women: Platform of Action on Women

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI have just returned from China, where I met with the All China Women's Federation on Beijing and after, and we talked about the work being done by both our governments towards the meeting in New York in June next year. Next month, the Office of the Status of Women will be represented at a regional meeting in Thailand on Beijing Plus 5.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I do not think Senator Crossin understands. I was not giving her any excuses. I was demonstrating that Australia is actively involved, and continues to be actively involved, at the most senior levels in our region in preparing for Beijing Plus 5. This government has a proud record on the work that has been done since Beijing, and it has been a very important element of the work of the Office of the Status of Women in preparing our report for the UN.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. The Australian Federal Police celebrates its 20th anniversary this week with the tabling of its annual report. Will the minister inform the Senate of the challenges for the Australian Federal Police in its next 20 years?

âI thank Senator Lightfoot for the question. The creation of a national police force by the Fraser government in 1979 was a response to Australia's developing international links. It was becoming clear that an increasingly mobile world population meant that borders alone were no barrier to serious crime. At the end of the 1990s, we can see new forms of crime and smarter ways of committing old crimes. Crime is now global. The criminals who inflict most damage on our community are sophisticated business people who command criminal enterprises stretching across the globe. They feed off drug smuggling, arms dealing, money laundering, technology based fraud and paedophile networks that span the globe and use the Internet in other ways. It is much more than the old break-and-enter or handling stolen videos. In that context, intelligence needs to guide and shape police operations, strategy and policy rather than simply support isolated investigations.

answer.para: Traditional policing was reactive rather than proactiveâa bit like firemen waiting around a station waiting around for someone to yell out that there was some smoke. Intelligence played a part but it did not actually drive or lead police work. Proactive policing means carefully selecting the targets that will maximise the impact on criminal activity. New technologies are providing ever widening opportunities for the development of sophisticated tools to support intelligence analysis. The federal government has ensured that the Australian Federal Police is able to face these challenges and is better funded than ever before. But do not take my word for it alone. Commissioner Palmer had this to say recently:
This organisationâ
that is the Australian Federal Policeâ
has never enjoyed a higher reputation, has never enjoyed better funding

talk.start.para: âOh yeah?

âAnd wait for it, Senator Bolkus, because there is more. The AFP is coming out of a number of years of tight fiscal constraint. It has never been more strongly supported by any government in its history. It has never been better funded, and it has never had a brighter future. I did not notice any police commissioner saying that when Labor occupied these benches.

answer.para: In addition, the federal government takes a lead role in supporting all of Australia's police services and law enforcement services such as AUSTRAC and of course Crimtrac. AUSTRAC is the agency that tracks money laundering and which develops some of the most innovative software to track suspect money. It plays a vital role in Australia's criminal investigations and intelligence systems. Crimtrac is a new national police information system which we need to provide the state-of-the-art information systems that are so vital for the support of effective intelligence. It is supported by a $50 million commitment from the federal government.

Twenty years ago, the largest seizure in the AFP's annual report was $66,000 worth of LSD. The AFP's annual report this year details seizures including nearly 400 kilos of heroin, worth $400 million, and 225 kilos of cocaine.

There is so much to sayâI hope Senator Lightfoot takes the opportunity to ask me a supplementary. There is just so much to say about the Federal Police, I do not know which bit to choose. In any event, if I do not get there, Senator Lightfoot, I will not forget you if there is more to ask.

I can announce that the AFP in Melbourne has seized 12 kilos of the designer drug ecstasyâthat is almost 45,000 tabletsâin what is believed to be the largest single seizure of the drug ever in Victoria. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a delegation from the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, led by the Vice-Chairman of the conference, Mr Wang Zhaoguo. âMadam President, I am not really sure whether Senator Mackay is interested in the answer. âWould the minister take the question on notice and also answer the following supplementary question. talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. âI regret to say that I do not know the full content of proposed resolution 76(R). But, if it is in the terms that the honourable senator outlined to us a moment ago, it would seem to be consistent with Australian government policy.

subdebateinfo.title: Office of the Status of Women: Director

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Newman, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is it true that the government will not be undertaking a normal recruitment process for the now vacant position of Director of the Office of the Status of Women but has instead commissioned a headhunting agency to find a suitable candidate? Senator NEWMAN

Senator NEWMAN

answer.para: I thought you may be interested, Senator, in an article I was reading today in the October-November edition of Access, which is a disability journal. subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders: Small Business

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Employment and business development are important areas of government policy in encouraging self-empowerment among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Will the minister please outline the latest government initiatives which aim to develop employment and the creation of small businesses for indigenous people?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferris for the question and for her continued interest in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I have a good news story today. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that this morning the government launched the $11 million Indigenous Small Business Fund. The fund is another element of the Howard government's $115 million indigenous employment policy, which forms part of our ongoing commitment to creating real employment opportunities for indigenous Australians. I congratulate the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, and his department for their dedication and hard work in putting this policy together.

answer.para: I am also pleased that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Chairman, Gatjil Djerrkura, has so strongly supported the government's initiatives. Today, Mr Djerrkura said of the fund:

It has demonstrated how ATSIC and the government can work together to seek to bring about real progress in bridging the gap of indigenous disadvantage. The government and ATSIC both recognise we must increase the economic independence of our people.

Madam President, you would be aware that since taking over this portfolio this has been one of the strengths of what we have contributed over the last 3Â½ years to Aboriginal people in the sense that we have supported them in their desire for economic independence and real jobs.

Under this $11 million Indigenous Small Business Fund, a total of $6 million will be provided by the government and another $5 million in funding will come from ATSIC. The Indigenous Small Business Fund will foster the development of businesses owned, operated and managed by indigenous people and help to promote sustained employment opportunities. Funds will be provided to indigenous organisations to develop services which provide entrepreneurship and business facilitation training. That has been one of the deficiencies up to date. It will also clarify business opportunities, develop business plans and proposals, and provide support and advice services to indigenous small business owner-operators in developing their skills, markets and networks.

As I have previously told the Senate, this government has sought to do things differently in indigenous affairs and we are starting to see the results. Three and half years ago I might not have said that I regarded my portfolio with enthusiasm, but what I have seen in the last 3Â½ years has encouraged me to the extent that I believe there is a sea change occurring in Aboriginal affairs in this country as a direct result of those people who are seeking out business opportunities and looking for education. As I mentioned the other day, we now have 44,000âone in five adult Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peopleâwho are going through vocational education and training courses. I have been fortunate to meet many talented, hardworking indigenous Australians with successful business ventures and terrific business ideas.

We have sought to foster economic empowerment among indigenous Australians through education, training, the creation of jobs and the development of successful indigenous businesses. I am pleased to say that the government has assisted in the creation of many indigenous enterprises over the past three years, including Queensland Bulk Haulage and, as I mentioned previously, Harbour Dreaming. I had the great pleasure recently of being part of the official launch of both those businesses which are providing indigenous Australians with jobs, income and a future. Queensland Bulk Haulage is but one. If Senator Ferris wishes to ask me about other businesses, I would be happy to provide her with further information, because there are so many.

Queensland Bulk Haulage at Cloncurry in north-western Queensland has just opened a new transport depot and was awarded the road haulage contract by Ernest Henry Mining to transport copper-gold concentrate. Queensland Bulk Haulage is a joint venture partnership between Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation, McIver Transport and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. Harbour Dreaming is an indigenous tourist venture on Sydney Harbour which is operated by the Redfern Aboriginal Corporation, and I congratulate Lee Silva. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would be very interested in hearing any further information that the minister could provide to the Senate about indigenous businesses and the prosperity they bring to Aboriginal communities.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferris for the supplementary question, because I also wanted to mention Gumala Enterprises and Charlie Smith at Mount Tom Price, where three separate enterprises are occurring. Harbour Dreaming offers cruises and charters to around 40 people and is well placed to take advantage of the great demand for indigenous culture during the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games.

answer.para: The Indigenous Small Business Fund is an example of the genuine partnerships being fostered between the government and indigenous people for the betterment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. There is a great untapped potential within indigenous communities, and I encourage business operators to employ indigenous Australians or go into partnership with them because the benefits can be very rewarding. It is all there. It is happening. I think the good news about what is happening should overcome the bad image that appears to be present in the community about the wonderful indigenous people of this country. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. The coalition government has been very active in helping the circumstances of older Australians. I invite the minister to advise the Senate of trends in the take-up by older Australians of income stream products such as annuities and how this builds on earlier initiatives of this government.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âWhat a delight to get an intelligent question that goes to policy.
âThere are so few of them around these days.
âCertainly there are very few around in this chamber today.
âAn intelligent senator.

âA very intelligent senator and a colleague and a friend. I am delighted. Madam President, retirees have been recognised by and been given priority under this government with tax reform and earlier initiatives of this government, and that has been recognised by retiree organisations. There has been a very favourable response from both customers and industry to the introduction of the new income stream rules.

answer.para: Since 20 September last year, changes to means testing rules for the pension have seen the sales of long-term income stream products increase significantly. For instance, the sales of lifetime and term annuities have increased 46 per cent in the year to June. Similarly, the sales of short-term products have declined. This is the behaviour the legislation was intended to encourage. These developments are welcomed by the government as they help to ensure that retired Australians are receiving regular secure income throughout their retirement years. The long-term security of these products is an attractive feature to many retirees, and the government welcomes the large scale take-up of the products.

Since September 1998, figures have shown that the sales of long-term assets test complying products have increased markedly over the previous year. The coalition has a solid record in support of pensioners and seniors generally. The linking of pensions to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings has meant that the maximum partnered rate has increased by $11 a fortnight for each person, more than would have applied with the cost of living increases alone. Expanding the entitlement for the Commonwealth seniors health card has meant that up to 220,000 self-funded retirees are now eligible for that card for the first time.

We have expanded carers' initiatives. We have introduced the pension bonus scheme. Taxpayers are able to contribute to their spouses' superannuationâwhich is terribly important for women in caring roles, for example. The provision of retirement savings accounts has provided flexibility for people. The health insurance rebate helps 850,000 over-65-year-olds and over 700,000 low income families. The pension payday is giving people choice and flexibility and there are now free annual health check-ups for over-75 year-olds, the majority of whom are women.

A prime concern of our government is that pensioners and retirees receive their fair share of the benefits of tax reform. Pensioners and seniors will greatly benefit under tax reform from lower income tax rates and a higher tax threshold. We have abolished provisional tax, which was a Labor tax. We have abolished sales tax, another Labor tax, financial institutions duty and the bank accounts debits tax. Pensioners and low income retirees will not pay a cent of taxation until their income reaches $14,500 for a single person or $24,500 for a couple. Pensioners and retirees may be eligible for bonus payments of up to $1,000 or $3,000 respectively, depending on their income and savings.

An additional 45,000 current self-funded retirees will become eligible for age pensions due to the relaxation of the pension income assets test. That gives them access to pensioner concession cards and all the associated benefits. Pensioners will be able to keep up to 60c in the dollar from their private incomeâthat is up by 10c in the dollar. When selling that business to retire it will be free of capital gains taxâonce again, Labor's tax. That all contrasts with Labor's recent appalling record and the `l-a-w law' tax cuts, which were not delivered. In fact, Labor increased taxes and older Australians will never forget it.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

Senator NEWMAN

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âYesterday Senator Faulkner asked a question about magnetic resonance imaging. I have an answer for him. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ
SENATOR FAULKNER asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, without notice, on 19 October 1999:

Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Health this morning repeated the claim that he was the one who initiated the current HIC investigation into the MRI scandal? Can the Minister confirm that in a Community Affairs Senate Estimates hearing on 4 May 1999 when Senator Herron was the Minister at the table, Mr Watzlaff from the Health Insurance Commission stated that he initiated the investigation following an anonymous tip-off and that he did not seek any advice or authority from the Minister to do so? Can Minister Herron explain this discrepancy?
SENATOR HERRON âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:

Prior to MRI being included on the Medicare Benefits Schedule on 1 September last year, the Minister for Health and Aged Care agreed to include a series of restrictions and controls to ensure that the supply of MRI could be managed.
The detail of these proposed requirements was provided to Dr Wooldridge by his Department on 7 August 1998 so that the regulations relating to the introduction of MRI could be completed.
It was at this stage that the Department advised the Minister of rumours relating to speculative orders being placed prior to the Budget.
It was made very clear that there were no allegations of substance, but there was a degree of rumour and innuendo.

The Department advised that if a process was put into place whereby statutory declarations were required of providers, this would be one way in which to ensure only genuine orders would be eligible for rebates.
The Minister agreed to implementation of such a process in order to ensure that the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) would be able to follow up any non-genuine orders.

On 19 August 1998, Dr Wooldridge signed the regulations relating to the introduction of MRI, and including a requirement for the submission of statutory declarations in relation to the eligibility of equipment.
This regulation set the framework allowing the HIC to review each application for eligibility and investigate where they had doubts
As a result the HIC was in a position to follow up information they received in December 1998, and commence investigations by the HIC's investigation unit.
The December anonymous information alluded to lodgement of false documents.
In July of this year, the HIC advised that they had encountered difficulties relating to the procurement of evidence in respect of their investigations.
Their powers under Part IID of the Health Insurance Commission Act were invoked, which means that they are able to summons information where that information is not being readily provided.

The important point is that when Dr Wooldridge agreed to the implementation of the new MRI arrangements, he was determined to ensure that the HIC would be in a position to follow up any wrongdoing on the part of providers.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Women's Representation on Advisory Committees

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked today.

The first thing I would like to do is go to the answer that Senator Newman provided to Senator Lundy. Senator Lundy asked a pretty simple question: what was the number of women on the Howard government's advisory committees on the GST and what was the role that OSW played in relation to the ANTS package, and GST in particular? It came as no surprise to people on this side of the chamber that the minister did not know. Why would the minister not know? It is because the minister does not go to OSW estimates. In fact, in the three years that I have been in the Senate since this government has been in power, I do not think the minister has ever gone to an OSW estimates. She is always represented by Senator Hill, who I suspect does a better job than Senator Newman would.

talk.start.para: âI find it a learning experience.

âIt would be more of a learning experience for Senator Newman, I suspect. That is why she didn't know. If she had gone to the estimates, what she would have known was that we asked Ms Goward, the head of OSW, precisely what involvement the OSW had with GST. Ms Goward confirmed that OSW was not formally consulted in relation to the ANTS package and GST in particular. To their credit, off their own bat, they put a submission to the government in relation to the ANTS package but they were not formally consulted. This is in relation to a piece of legislation that is probably one of the most significant over the last couple of decades.

speech.para: One may say, looking at the record of this government in relation to women: why would the government bother asking the OSW in relation to the ANTS package? They probably would not want to hear it. Given their record on women, why would they bother with the consultation? There is a very good reason, and that is that the Prime Minister himself issued an edict that all legislation had to be considered by the Office of the Status of Women. On the ANTS package the OSW was not given the opportunity to be consulted in relation to it or to provide feedback. I wonder why. Is it because they would not have liked what they heard or is it more the case that they forgot? I suspect they forgot to consult the Office of the Status of Women.

This is extraordinary. Even some of the most unreconstructed ministers on the other side of the chamber in estimates are aware of the Prime Minister's edict that the OSW needs to be consulted. Even some of the most thin-skinned ministers are aware of it. Even Senator Macdonald was aware of it when I asked him about it in estimates.
Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI thought that was extraordinary, Senator Faulkner. However, he thought it was quite hilarious that we asked a number of questions about women in his department, including how many women there are in the SES, how many women there are on overseas trips and so on. Then we go to the fairly bizarre answer to Senator Gibbs. Clearly, Senator Newman either completely misunderstood or did not knowâI am not sureâbut it was clarified.
âIt was probably deliberate.

âProbably she deliberately obfuscated, I would suggest. However, it was clarified for her by Senator Faulkner in the final question. The bottom line is that Senator Newman indicated that the ads were placed on 15 October. We knew that. âOr a girl guide.

âDon't put down that you're a girl guide; don't put down that you are an older woman; don't put down that your sexuality may be more out of the mainstream than the rest of society's; and don't put down that you disagree with the government. speech.para: It is about time there was this much-vaunted reshuffle of the frontbench that was reported in the newspapers today. I can say that there would not be many that ought to survive. talk.start.para: âI really feel like saying, `Phone New York and bring Robert Ray back,' because since he has been gone the questions from the rabble on the other side have deteriorated to the point where they are absolutely hopeless. There is no structure, there is nothing about policy; there is just nitpicking at the edges. That is all they can do.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner, I can do without the interjections. I would ask Senator Patterson to be careful with the language she uses in describing honourable senators.

âSenator Mackay said that Senator Newman did not go to estimates. People listening would need to understand that Senator Newman is not required to be at those estimates. Senator Hill attends those estimates as the minister representing the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. But let me remind people that, when Dr Lawrence was minister for women's affairs and she had women's roundtables, she would float in at the beginning, say a few words to people and float out again. When Senator Newman became the minister for women's affairs, the roundtable commented on the fact that she stayed for the whole time. She actually stays and listens. speech.para: Senator Newman was asked by the other side about a Beijing Plus 5 preparatory meeting in the Philippines. After the question was asked, Senator Newman received advice from DFAT that no meeting on Beijing Plus 5 was held in the Philippines that they were aware of. There was an NGO meeting on Beijing Plus 5 in Bangkok at that time. Let us ask the opposition to go back, start again, get a new questions committee and get Senator Conroy to ring Uncle RobertâSenator Rayâin New York to get his advice on questions, because the opposition has been doing abysmally since he has been away.

Senator Newman was also asked a question about advertising in the disability area. We need to go back and remind the Labor Partyâthey need to be reminded constantly of what they did in governmentâthat their policy was to close down what were then called sheltered workshops because they had the view that every single person in a sheltered workshopânow called a business enterpriseâwas capable of open employment. We had one of the most moving times in the Senate when people spoke about some of the problems associated with employing people with disabilities. Former Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen spoke about her role as patron of an organisation that runs a large number of sheltered workshops. Senator Herron got up and made a most profound speech as the father then of a young woman with a severe disability who was in a sheltered workshop.

That speech shamed the Labor Party and shamed Senator Tate into demanding that the then minister, Mr Howe, do something about it. The road we were on was one of closing down sheltered workshops. It was an absolutely appalling policy. That is the sort of thing Labor did for people with disabilities. That is the sort of record they had. They had to back off and change because they were made aware by the people running what are now called business enterprises and by the parents that there was a place for employing young people with profound disabilities in an environment where they were safe and secure and could be trained and that, hopefully, some of them would move into open employment.

The other thing the opposition did when it was advertising the disability reform packageâand Senator Newman has been criticised about advertising on disability issuesâwas to give a $5 million contract to a company called Corporate Impacts. That company was balance sheet insolvent when it got the contract, but nobody did a Dun and Bradstreet check on the company. So what happened? It was a contract that was let with no lead departmentâSocial Security, Education and Health were involved in it. It went down the drain. One of the outcomes was that little companies that employed people with disabilities did not get their money. Not only did the advertising project fail but also people with disabilities were left without money, and the information was not passed on. That is the opposition's record in government. So to come in here and criticise Senator Newman is absolutely over the top. The opposition needs to be doing something about getting some policies of its own, getting on with it, and being a decent opposition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSenator Newman has well deserved the criticism after today. Today was a perfect example: a number of questions were asked of Senator Newman, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and when she did not have a brief, she could not answer the question. When she did have a brief, she just read it off, like anyone can do when reading a speech. She was asked a number of questions today and she floundered. To a question I specifically asked her in relation to a meeting that was held overseas in the Philippines, she talked about how she had just returned from China. She told us about the Office of the Status of Women and what activities they have planned for next month. That had nothing at all to do with the question that I had asked. The question she was asked was: why did we fail to send an official to that meeting overseas? Not only thatâwhy did we not send a female representative, as we saw with the delegation that went to the ILO conference? Who else did not send any representation to that meeting overseas? Malaysia, Indonesia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, the Islamic Republic of Iranânot countries, with all due respect, that you would hold up on a pedestal as having an astounding record in relation to what they do for women. So we have now joined that category, have we? In relation to this minister and her portfolio, that would be right.

speech.para: Let us move on to Ms Goward leaving the Office of the Status of Women. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is not dealing with that recruitment; Morgan & Banks are. Let us ask ourselves this: why has Ms Goward chosen to go? Is it because the Prime Minister desperately needs a spokesperson on the Olympics? No, he has got thatâhe has a minister for sport. Or is it because Ms Goward said, `I'm pretty tired of the fact that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet keep changing my briefs and changing my letters, won't allow me to invite who I want to invite to the roundtable, won't allow me to have the consultations that I want to have with women in the community and won't allow me to put in place the initiatives that I want'?

Is it not a factâand members of the public may want to consider thisâthat in whatever Ms Goward has tried to do over the course of her employment, she has been stopped time and time again by particular people in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet? Is it not a last resort thatâinstead of resigning and causing Senator Newman the ultimate embarrassmentâshe has been offered another sweetener by the Prime Minister? So I dangle that idea for people of the public and for people in the press gallery to contemplate. She is a strong personâwhy has she not been able to have the influence that the head of the Office of the Status of Women ought to have?

Why do we not have a Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women who is able to represent women across the board? How do women from a non-English speaking background now feed in their concerns to this government? They do not get funding; they have not been invited to the roundtable. How do people from the Justice Coalition or from women's legal centres survive? How do people who are running community based organisations such as the Girl Guides, who have had their funding reduced from $50,000 to $20,000, feel? In the annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which was tabled last week, we saw that around 50 to 60 organisations were invited to the roundtable last year, and this year we see that there are only going to be 20 and a certain number of individuals. Hand-picked by whom? By Jocelyn Newman? By the Prime Minister? By the Office of the Status of Women? That is yet to be revealed, and we may never know the answer to that.

In closing, one thing I want to say in relation to the performance of this minister is that the National Council of Women was one of the three organisations that received funding to establish a secretariat, but it does not have a presence in the Northern Territory, the electorate which I represent. What kind of research was undertaken to ensure that women right around this countryânot just those on the eastern seaboardâare represented and share in the money that is dished out to women's organisations? The YWCA and the BPW in the Northern Territory have a base in Darwin only. So rural and remote women of this country miss out once more, but it is not surprising under this minister. It is what women of Australia have come to expect, and they do not like it. They do not like the fact that they are being marginalised, being si lenced and do not have the opportunity to be listened to by this government.

talk.start.para: âIn rising to speak on this taking note of answers, I want to refer briefly to the comments made by those on the other side in relation to Senator Newman's participation, particularly in the estimates on the Office of the Status of Women. As a member, for example, of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee, I spendâas Madam Deputy President West doesâhours and hours in those estimates hearings, more often than not with Senator Newman in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Any suggestion whatsoever that she does not do her job, that she does not fulfil her role in that regard, is one which I would absolutely reject and which should be rejected. It is a very unfortunate reflection on the minister and on my colleague the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, who does an extraordinarily good job in that role in the Office of the Status of Women estimates, in particular in his capacity as a former shadow minister in that very portfolio. So it cannot be said that he is without skills or experience in that regard.

speech.para: Speakers opposite have addressed this afternoon the role of the Office of the Status of Women. There are a couple of points that I want to make in relation to this government's achievements and initiatives for womenâin which the OSW has played a significant roleâand I think it is important that those are on the record. Let us talk very briefly about those in the general economic area first. There is no regard whatsoever paid to the $13 billion of income tax cuts, and increased assistance to families to the extent of $2Â½ billion is completely ignored. That benefit to women is completely ignored by those opposite.

Let me refer briefly to some health measures which I have spoken about in this chamber before. What about the special measures for women's health which have included $8.2 million for a fly-in-fly-out female general practitioner service for rural Australiaâfor some of the very areas that Senator Crossin was just referring to? There is also an extra $4.1 million for specialised health care for women diagnosed with breast cancer and a further $8.1 million for the National Breast Cancer Centreâin fact, I think next week is National Breast Cancer Week. These are achievements and initiatives of this government for Australian women which are worth recording and noting for the record.

Under this government, women's participation in paid work is recognised as vital to their economic security. Around 64 per cent of working age women participate in the paid labour force. Since the government took office in 1996, employment for women has increased by almost 260,000 from March of that year, an increase of 7.2 per cent. In August of this year, just a couple of months ago, the unemployment rate for women reached seven per cent, its lowest level since 1990. These are figures which ought to be on the record and should be recognised by those opposite as important figures for women in the community.

One of the programs that I have referred to previously in the chamber is the $22.4 million for the Return to Work Program for peopleâmainly women in this particular componentâwho are seeking to return to the work force after an absence for two or more years due to parenting or caring responsibilities. This is an important support initiative. It recognises that people who are out of the work force for a particular period of time may need some support at re-entry, whether it is in training or in development of skills to actually go through the job interview process. All of those elements are there and are being supported by the government in the Return to Work Program. But is there any acknowledgment of that from the other side? None whatsoever.

The Work and family state of play report has provided more solid evidence of the success of the government's efforts in promoting more family friendly workplaces. About 67 per cent of certified agreements and 79 per cent of AWAs approved under the Workplace Relations Act now include one or more family friendly measures. We have recently reviewed the operation of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act to ensure that it operates more effectively for both women and business. In relation to search issues, which have been raised in the chamber today, the government remains committed to increasing diversity amongst Australian decision makers. We have extended the Executive Search Pilot Program and what is known as the early warning system initiatives for Commonwealth boards and provided funding towards the National Women's Leadership Project to promote women onto private sector boards. These are all important initiatives and these are all components of the government's efforts in relation to our achievements and initiatives for women, and all should have greater recognition than they have received from those opposite.

talk.start.para: âSenator Gibbs asked perhaps the most significant question asked today in this debate, and it was later followed up by Senator Faulkner. Both those people asked about the basis upon which the person who will run the Office of the Status of Women is going to be chosen. Clearly, this side of the chamber is very concerned to ensure that that person is chosen according to criteria that will best serve not only the women of Australia but people in Australia generally. You have to understand that when we talk about women of Australia we are talking about citizens, and very vital citizens, whether they be women in their nineties who live alone, who have raised a family and who have now become great-grandmothers; whether they be women who have raised a family but are still working hard in various professions and in various jobs and professions, performing well in those roles; or whether they be younger women who adorn our sports fields or work in offices or run companies.

speech.para: There is a whole spread of women, and I would have thought that the person who is going to fill the office that looks after that range of people is very important and that the selection should not be left to Morgan and Banks. I am not big on people who specialise in getting people employed. It seems extraordinary to me that a government is not in a position to know exactly what it wants in terms of the person who is going to look after the interests of women. Why would you go off to a firm like Morgan and Banks? Who are Morgan and Banks? What are the criteria that have been given to Morgan and Banks for them to test? I have always had great problems with getting people selected to positions by some company that holds out an expertise. For example, Senator Susan Ryan adorned the Senate when we were down the hill. Senator Hill will remember Senate Ryan well. If Senator Ryan were still here, this is a job she would undertake personally because she would attach a great deal of importance to it.

talk.start.para: âI thought that for an ALP minister she was very able.

âSenator Hill said she was able. I think he might have put a condition on that, but I am sure he does not mean the condition to be in any way derogatory, because she was an outstanding member of this chamber and I think among the first women in this country to be a minister.

speech.para: In any event, the point I want to make is this. The government should have gone about the choice of this office as an exercise of the greatest importance. Senator Faulkner would bear this out, and so would Senator Hill. I do not think for one moment that the Prime Minister when he is choosing his cabinet goes off to Morgan and Banks. Perhaps he does. Perhaps the people in the party room are interviewed by Morgan and Banks to see whether or not they should have a ministry! If the Prime Minister and his office do not go off to Morgan and Banks to choose the ministry, why does the Prime Minister go off there to choose a person of almost equal importance, I would suggest, that is, the person who is going to look after the various concerns that women may have? As I say, there is such a wide range of women who work hard trying to bring up their children, whether they be women on the factory floor, women who work in the shop or professional women. Across that broad range of people, they need to be properly cared for, and the person who is going to be in charge of the Prime Minister's concern for them should be chosen according to proper criteria and should be chosen by the Prime Minister and by the cabinet itself. That is what should happen. I think Morgan and Banks should butt out and others should come in. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSpeaking generally, I believe this government has delivered on its commitments to enhance opportunities for Australian women through strong economic growth, tax reform and better and simpler assistance for families and those in need. As for everyone else in Australia, for womenâparticularly as they are often the carers for familiesâit is very important that the economy be strong and doing very well. Senator Payne outlined what this government has done in terms of the economy, tax concessions and an extra $2Â½ billion in assistance to families. That is very important. I will mention just a couple of other things and then get on to the broader issue. Women also benefit from measures to increase support in relationship education for families.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Carr!

âLet me address Senator Carr's problem. Let me do that right now. There is an unfortunate ideological subtext for a lot of what the Australian Labor Party does. Let me get into that. Labor believes that real women are left wing, that real women do not vote Liberalâthat's right, isn't it?âand that feminists, you see, have got to vote Labor.
âSenator Mason, you might like to address the chair, thank you.

interjection.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Carr, I will have order.

âMadam Deputy President, that is the unfortunate subliminal, ideological subtext of the Leftâabsolutely irrelevant. Of course, Labor believes that real women do not believe in equality of opportunity. Real women, according to the ALP, believe in equality of outcomes and quotas, including those for places in parliament. That is right: that is what it believes in. Real women, according to the ALP, believe in quotas. That is what the ALP believes in.

speech.para: Also, apparently, real women do not believe in mutual obligation. Real women, according to the ALP, do not believe in mutual obligation: they simply treat the state as the ever-weaning teat, as I mentioned the other day in taking note. That is what the Labor Party believes: real women have to be left wing. Fortunately, in the history of this Commonwealth most women have voted for the coalition. The women have done very, very well.

And the funny thing is that the great keenness with which the Labor Party talk about women is only directed towards women that vote Labor or are in the Labor Party. The greatest female politician of this century in the Western world was a conservative, and they would not acknowledge her: Mrs Thatcher, who changed theâ
Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is right: absolutely destroyed the Left and made the Labor Party move to the third way because they were so irrelevant. She did that, and they should be applauding women in politics. You know what: most women vote for the conservative side and most of them represent the conservative side, and that is the difference.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYes, because remember: real women on your side are left wing. Isn't that right, Senator? Real women are left wingâthat is what they believe. The ALP are very big on talk but very poor on outcomes and great on rhetoric but never on anything else. If they really believed in women in politics, they would parade Mrs Thatcher as a marvellous outcome, having thrashed the Left.

speech.para: In addition, the government has also released the national family strategy, which focuses on the need for social coalition, because the Labor Party do not believe in social coalitions; they simply believe in the state providing. The state loves you somehowâthat is what they believe, but we do not believe in that. This government has also given around $20 million for respite support for carers of younger people with profound and severe disabilities, and an extra $8.2 million for carers of dementia sufferers. But I would like to conclude on this: the subliminal text of the ALP is that real women vote Labor. Real women vote Liberal and most have in the history of this country, and we support themâas outlined by Senator Payne and Senator Newman.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

para.inline: Health Insurance Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.5) Statutory Rules 1999 No.176

speech.para: Item 1 of the Schedule adds seven item numbers which, if requested by oral and maxillofacial surgeons, will be within the Medicare Benefits Schedule. para.inline: National Health Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.4) Statutory Rules 1999 No.174

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Brown) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Customs Act 1901 to prohibit the importation of radioactive substances for storage in Australia.
Motion (by Senator Brown) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

Overwhelmingly, the Australian community and political parties reject proposals to dump the world's nuclear waste in Australia. Yet Pangea Resourcesâwhose dominant shareholder is the British Government-owned British Nuclear Fuelsâcontinues to plan just that.

Pangea is targeting South Australia or Western Australia as the site for underground disposal of tens of thousands of tonnes of high and intermediate level waste from nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons around the world. It would be transported by ship and rail to be buried in a network of underground catacombs.
This bill will stop Pangea, or any similar proposals.

It closes a loophole in the Customs Act which would have allowed a future government to approve imports of nuclear waste from overseas, for disposal in Australia, without reference to parliament. The ban does not apply to waste originating from nuclear activities in Australia, recognising our obligation to dispose of the waste we create ourselvesâmostly from the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights in Sydney.
Passing this bill will give legislative backing to the community's rejection of the Pangea plan.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.
