If he does, perhaps he could let the government know because that could assist us in our investigations. We would welcome any assistance whatsoever from Senator Carr.

âThank you very much, Senator Ellison. I always appreciate those sorts of invitations and I am sure you, in due course, will come to regret them. Nonetheless, I take it in the spirit in which it has been offeredâand it is the same offer that Mr Ruddock has made to me on numerous occasionsâand I say to you I will be only too happy to continue to provide you with advice on how you can improve the operations of this particular area.
âConstructive, not furphies.

âIt is always constructive, Minister. What I am particularly concerned aboutâand I come back to this point, and I have not had an answer from you on thisâis this issue: has the department been advised of foreign language advertisements circulating in this country, particularly in the Korean press, about the operations of certain colleges, many of whom I have named? Has it been advised of those complaints, and what action has it taken on those complaints?

speech.para: I refer specifically here to the issue of advertisements in the foreign language press outlining the activities of various agents, whether they be immigration or education agents, which I claim in fact involve breaches of the law; namely, offering people moneyâwith the claim that they can fix their bank balance, offering inducements to people to appear at various colleges, making claims that they can fix attendance problems and that they can fix up visas, and other such activities which would appear to me to fit into the category of misleading and deceptive conduct. Have such claims been made to the department and what action has the ministry undertaken on those matters?

talk.start.para: âAs I said earlier, the advertisements have been drawn to the attention of the department and action has been taken in relation to the investigation of them. I really cannot take it much further other than to say that it is under investigation.
âWhen was that action taken? Was the action taken after these matters were raised in the Senate?

âI foreshadowed this earlier when I said that a number had been received but I was not sure whether they were the same ones Senator Carr was referring to because he had not sufficiently described the instances he was referring to. Senator Carr is asking me when we actioned an investigation into those ones that he is referring to. Before I can answer that I need some detail as to the dates of the advertisements and where they appeared. Then I could assist Senator Carr further.

âIn debate I have raised a series of advertisements and I think the departmental officials are only too aware of those advertisements in the Woori Magazine circulated in the Korean community. Have those inquiries been investigated?

âI think it would be a good idea if Senator Carr could give us a copy of those because we might be at cross-purposes here. The ones I have been advised of might not necessarily be the ones you are referring to. You say you mentioned them previously in debate; I would like you to point to where that has been debated previously. Senator Carr has not mentioned this in question time to me previously or in any other debate that I have been involved in. If Senator Carr could table them or provide them to us, we are only too willing to look into them.

âI do realise that Senator Carr is pursuing a line of questioning, but I have a couple of queries of the minister. Firstly, does the minister agree with Dr Kemp's assessment that `already eight institutions appear to be operating at a deficit and some regional campuses are at risk'? I would like his response to that. Does he agree with that? I am wondering if he can shed some light on the time line in relation to Dr Kemp's statement in response to funding issues in higher education. The statement we are anticipating is in part a response to the West report. I am wondering when we can expect the next instalment from Dr Kemp in relation to his assessment of funding matters as distinct from his cabinet-in-confidence submissions, which we have already seen.

âThe minister has made it quite clear that he is not aware of any regional campuses being at risk of closure. I think the minister has already said that regional universities are no exception to the reality that there is always a variety of risks for complex organisations like universities, and managing these risks is always a challenge for good management. To highlight and to perhaps even distort the situation in relation to regional universities does them no good.

speech.para: Certainly, the government is keen to afford a system which provides opportunities for those students in regional Australia and regional universities. I think the minister has also said that he does not deny that some universities will need to continue to modify the way in which they operate in order to meet the challenges that are posed by operating in regional Australia. But to suggest that the actions of this government put at risk the existence of regional universities is totally false and the government would reject that.

As I have stated, the government are committed to giving greater flexibility to universities and to ensuring that the bureaucratic regulation and controls which inhibit their operations are minimised. We are about assisting those universities to make it easier for them to operate and not to tangle them up in regulation and formality.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for his response. I did not actually state or suggest that the government was responsible for putting regional universities at risk. That was not the purpose of my question. I just wanted to know if the minister agreed with the relevant minister's exact words, which were `some regional campuses are at risk'. It is fairly simple: either you agree with his assessment or you do not.

speech.para: I also had another question. I understand that the minister was taking advice when I asked it. My query was on the next paper from Dr David Kemp, in part relating to the government's response to the West review and also relating to funding for higher education. I was wondering what the time line on that paper was. When can we expect that?

In relation to the scholarships, I am wondering if the government provided money to universities for the purposes of administering the scholarships and advertising those scholarships. I am conscious that one of the concerns that came back from universities during this survey, if you like, by the government was that it was difficult. Perhaps they did not advertise them broadly enough. I take on board the minister's response that it was administratively complex. I am just wondering what assistance the government provided to universities in order to ensure that those complexities were minimised so that you would have a scheme that did what it was intended to doâthat is, assist those students from genuinely disadvantaged backgrounds, students who, I might add, will not have this form of assistance in future.

talk.start.para: âIn relation to Senator Stott Despoja's first questionâdo I agree with the minister's commentsâI think she was quoting from a leaked document which I am not aware of as having any authenticity. We have repeatedly asked for the document to be tabled. I do not comment on documents which have been leaked illegally. The document is entirely hearsay; it is a document which purports to be something.
âHearsay?

âDocuments are hearsay. Any court of law will tell you that, Senator O'Brien. We have here a document, unsubstantiated, which the Democrats are asking me to pass comment on. I am not able to pass comment on a document I have not seen, which is unsubstantiated and which purports to be something which it might not be. To say that they are the words of the minister is totally inappropriate and totally incorrect.

âI am wondering again whether the minister will answer the first question. Even if he does not know, do we have a time line on the release of the paper by Dr Kemp that looks into funding issues and is, in part, a response to the West paper? I put on record that the authenticity or the legitimacy of that document has not been denied. I quote from one part of a 7.30 Report transcript, where Kerry O'Brien asks Dr David Kemp a question based on the document:

speech.para: KERRY O'BRIEN: This document says that under the current system, your current system, "Higher student staff ratios, less frequent lecture and tutorial contact, the persistence of outdated technology in key areas of professional prevention are fuelling a perception of declining quality." A perception or a reality, Dr Kemp?
DAVID KEMP: You ask the universities.
KERRY O'BRIEN: These are your words, aren't they?
DAVID KEMP: That's what I've saidâ- a perception of declining quality.

Is the minister suggesting that this is not an authentic document from David Kemp? Is he stating for the record now that the document is hearsay? Is he disowning this document as a government document, albeit a leaked cabinet-in-confidence document? Is he seriously suggesting that the authenticity of this document has been denied? As far as I am concerned, it has not been denied, and most of the media reports would support that. I look forward to the minister stating categorically that this is not a government document.

talk.start.para: âI am unable to provide a time line to Senator Stott Despoja. I do not think I can take it further than that. This is something the government is looking at, and it really is something that I cannot assist Senator Stott Despoja any further on.

âI thank the minister for that answer. The paper is authored, we believe, by Dr David Kemp, and this has not been denied by the minister as being his document. I would like to hear whether the minister is honestly suggesting to the chamber that that is not a cabinet-in-confidence document from Minister Kemp.
âI seek clarification as to which document Senator Stott Despoja is referring to.
âThe one that I quoted from, that Kerry O'Brien quoted from, the cabinet-in-confidence document that is Dr Kemp's views on the higher education sectorâone that I am sure you have seen, Minister.

âI have not seen it. I have read a great deal about it and I have seen some excerpts, but I have not seen that document. I am not about to confirm whether anything is a cabinet document. That is a matter which is cabinet-in-confidence. That has been the practiceâit is a standard principle in relation to the operation of governmentâof this government and of governments since time immemorial before this one. I think it is a well-established practice which I am not about to break.

speech.para: I move request for amendment:
(1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (lines 14 and 15), omit paragraphs (l) and (m), substitute:
(l) in the case of the year 2000â$3,417,075,000; and
(m) in the case of the year 2001â$3,351,623,000.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to table certain documents that the minister has asked me about. These concern some questions I raised in the Senate on 30 September in the adjournment debate. The documents relate to a series of advertisements that appeared in the foreign language pressâin the 29th issue of the Woori Magazine , dated August this yearâand circulated in Australia. They purport to be advertisements concerning the operations of a number of colleges, particularly in Melbourne and Sydney. The names of the colleges are identified in English. The advertisements are in Korean, with translations that are purported to be and I have been given to believeâand I do so put to the Senate in good faithâare accurate translations. Obviously the department would be aware of the Senate debate, and I seek leave to table those documents now.
âOn the basis that Senator Carr has tendered them in good faith, and I understand that he states they are actual translations, I will grant leave.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI repeat that these translations have been given to me in good faith. I am of the view that the persons who gave them to me have acted in good faith. Not speaking Korean, I cannot personally verify that these are accurate in all respects, but I will table the documents and would like to speak to them. I indicate that the documents name a number of colleges that purport to offer students assistance and, in return for certain sums of money, to overcome what to me are clear problems with visas.

speech.para: For instance, Woori Magazine, in the 29th issue, identified the International Academy of Education and stated details of other colleges that are operating. They provide advertisements for the arrangement of visas and pathways to higher education. Their advertisement sought to claim their identification with a number of other institutions. An advertisement for Infinity Quest said that they were able to provide assistance to students. It said:
Please contact us if you do not have sufficient bank account balance. We solve the problems about attendance rate.
Another advertisement, for Prime, said:
1. We help students who do not have sufficient bank account balance.
2. Consultation for the attendance problems.
3. No agent fee is charged for your relatives and friends in Korea.
An advertisement for Hundai Gate says:
1. We lend up to $10,000 to students who do not have enough tuition fee
2. We help students who have attendance problems
3. We are able to make bank accounts balance for you
That is a tremendous service, as I have indicated on previous occasions. On page 31, an advertisement for Sogangâand it gives the address in Pitt Street in Sydneyâsays:
If you have troubles in extending your visa due to the attendance problem, we are able to solve such problems.

And so it goes on. I will table those documents. I ask these two questions again: have the department been contacted about these matters? Have they taken action since the matters were raised on 30 September?

talk.start.para: âThe department have not been contacted in relation to these advertisements and will look into the matters that Senator Carr has raised. I stress to the Senate that the mere raising of an allegation, of course, does not mean that that allegation has been found and proven. As a matter of fairness to the people who are mentioned in relation to these advertisements, they do very much enjoy the benefit of the doubt under our system of law. I would remind those who are listening and the Senate of that fact. But, in view of Senator Carr's comments, we will look into this, as we usually do, and I can assure him that that will be done.

âI thank the minister for his assurance on that matter, and I indicate that I do accept the spirit in which he has presented that assurance. I look forward to further discussion on that. I ask: what action has been taken in the case of the Business Institute of Victoria, which is a college whereâand the department have in previous times acknowledged thisâprima facie breaches of the law have occurred in relation to the offering of courses outside of the CRICOS list. It is a college that was given accreditation under the CRICOS list to run courses in security and cleaning but was offering courses in higher education, such as MBAs. The department have acknowledged prima facie breaches of the law, which I understand have penalties of some four years and other penalties of two years. What action has been taken in that matter?

âI will take that question on notice. I do not recall the department acknowledging any prima facie case. If that were done, an investigation might necessarily flow. I urge Senator Carr to be very careful in equating the acknowledgment of a prima facie case with a charge being laid or a finding of guilt. Normally the finding of a prima facie case results in a charge being laid. I am not aware of any charges being laid in that matter, but I will take it on notice.

âI do appreciate the difference. Given the seriousness of the allegations that have been made in the chamber, I therefore ask the minister: has the department prosecuted anybody for breaches of the ESOS Act in the last 12 months?
âMy advice is that there has been no prosecution in the last 12 months.
âWhen was the last time a prosecution was launched under this act?
âI will have to take that one on notice.

âMinister, is it the case that, under this act, these companies do not require independent audits of their accountsâthat is, independent of the companies themselves? Or is it the case that there is no government audit of the accounts of these companies? Is it the case that, under the operations of the international division at the moment, the government relies upon the advice of auditors provided by the companies themselves?
âAs I understand it, the government does not carry out an audit itself but that an independent auditor carries out such an audit. I think that answers Senator Carr's question.
âIs it the case that this so-called independent auditor is in fact provided by the company?
âAs I understand it, the company does choose the auditor but the auditor has to be independent. Auditors, of course, are not necessarily in the business of being bought and sold.
âYou are very brave.
âSenator Carr, it is an office which is a professional one. I think we are entitled to assume that auditors, just like lawyers and doctors and others, are professionals.

âAs I understand it, each year, on 30 June, audits are provided to the department at the discretion of the companies. How many qualified audits have been presented to the department for these providers as of today, and how many companies have failed to produce audited statements at all?

âI will take that question on notice. I can say at the outset that the selection of an auditor is compulsory; it is not discretionary. I think that is conceded. But the remainder of the question needs answering, and it will be taken on notice.
âHow many of the companies that I have actually named in this chamber have failed to produce non-qualified audit reports?
âAgain, I will take that on notice.

âI return briefly to the minister's suggestion that the document to which a number of us have referredâa document entitled `Proposals for Reform in Higher Education' which is attributed to Dr David Kempâis hearsay. I seek leave to table the transcript of the 7.30 Report from which I was reading. I have just had another glance at it and have highlighted Minister Kemp's responses where he has said things like:

speech.para: What we have said in the document is that we want universities to have flexibilities.
As any fair-minded reader of that document will see . . .
When Kerry O'Brien puts a quote to him from the document and asks, `Are you comfortable about universities charging higher fees?' Minister Kemp answers:
Well, what I was saying there was that the claims would be made.
Presumably `there' is the document. Kerry O'Brien says:
This document says that the deregulation of fees will allow the properlyâthe proposition of financed by taxpayersâthe proportion, sorry, financed by taxpayers to decrease.
Minister Kemp responds:
Well, there is no suggestion in this document about cutting funding to universities.

How many times can the minister refer to the document that nearly every person involved in education debates in Australia has seen and yet the ministerâwho, theoretically, should be more familiar with these proposals than just about anyone here because he is the minister representing the minister in this placeâseems to be suggesting that he has not seen the document. Further, is he suggesting that the document is hearsay when even David Kemp has not denied the authenticity of this document? If he insists that the document is hearsay, perhaps Dr David Kemp is talking about a different document. In that case, could we table that documentâbecause I think we would all be curious to see it.

Is the minister seriously suggesting, as the education minister and as the minister representing the minister for higher education in this place, that he has not seen the document which nearly every person in Australia has seen? My understanding isâand I will happily checkâthat it actually has been tabled in the parliament.

talk.start.para: âThe first issue is that Senator Stott Despoja has sought leave to table a document. Is leave granted?

âPerhaps I could be given a copy of that document before that question is put to me. In the absence of seeing it, I would have to say no. I think that that question is best deferred until I have had a chance to have a look at the document, and then I can advise the chamber as to whether leave is granted.

speech.para: In relation to another point, I think Senator Stott Despoja referred to me as the minister for education and the minister representing the minister for higher education. I think that was a slip. I am not the minister for either of those. Can I say that, as the minister representing the minister for education, in the normal course of my duties I would not see any document that Dr Kemp might or might not put up. It is really not in my portfolio; therefore when Senator Stott Despoja queries whether I have seen this document, I can honestly say I have not seen it, because it is not in my portfolio. I can only say that, from what I have heard to date, it is a document which purports to be something which it claims to be, which has not been substantiated.

I will have to look at this transcriptâin particular those points that have been highlighted. I will need a little time to have a look at that before I can advise the chamber as to whether leave is granted. Perhaps Senator Stott Despoja might carry on with something else and I can look at this in the meantime.

talk.start.para: âI am sorryâI acknowledge that the minister is representing the minister in this place in the debate. I am happy for leave to be denied. I have already read into the Hansard the relevant excerpts from the 7.30 Report . It is a transcript that was not written by me. It is from the Internet, from the ABC. I just thought it would be preferred by the minister that the transcript was tabled as opposed to my continually referring to it and reading from it. I am happy for you to deny leave. It is not a particularly scary document, but you should by now have a copy of the cabinet-in-confidence submission, which we are happy to table. I understand that that is acceptable to the opposition. I am very pleased that we could be the first people to show you that document. I am sorry that you had to get it from us. I would have thought that, in the normal course of events, you would have seen it, if not in the paper then from the relevant minister. I would have thought he would have provided that to you.

speech.para: I have to say that I find it extraordinary that a minister representing the minister for education in this place in this debate is suggesting that he has not seen that document.

talk.start.para: âCan I say that it has not been established that it is a cabinet-in-confidence document. I have had two documents handed to me. One is the transcript of an interview with Dr Kemp on the 7.30 Report . Leave is granted in relation to tabling that.
âIf there is no objection, leave is so granted.

âI have now been handed a second document, which purports to be cabinet-in-confidence. I have not had an opportunity to look at that document; therefore, leave is not granted, because it is normal to allow some time, and I think that is proper.

speech.para: Can I say that there is nothing extraordinary about a minister not seeing any cabinet submission which is not in his or her portfolio. That is not extraordinary. If Senator Stott Despoja is trying to make that so, then really it is in the face of standing practice. Ministers do not involve themselves in other minister's cabinet submissions in the normal course of events. If there is some dual involvement in putting it to cabinet, it might be a different story. But there is nothing untoward in that at all. I have not seen the document before, as Senator Stott Despoja has put to me, and I reject totally that there is anything untoward and that I should have seen it before. I am not aware of it having been published in full in any paper. I certainly have not looked it up on the Internet.

talk.start.para: âI was asking about the operation of the international division. I understand that 26 providers submitted statements regarding NTA funds accompanied by a qualified report from their auditor or otherwise identified as having failed to comply with one or more aspects of the financial and reporting requirements of the ESOS Act during the reporting period from 1 July 1998 to 30 June 1999. The identified instances of non-compliance have been: failure to notify the Secretary to the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs of NTA details; failure to deposit course monies in the NTA as soon as practicable; failure to comply with regulations governing withdrawals and payments from the NTA, resulting in shortfalls to the amount standing to the credit of students; failure to comply with refund provisions of student defaults; the depositing of money other then overseas students' pre-paid course money in the NTA, in contravention of the laws of trust; and incorrect particulars in the statement of NTA funds. I ask the minister: can he confirm that all of those 26 providers are now operating in accordance with the ESOS Act in terms of the reporting requirement?

âI will take that question on notice. I understand that there were some companies that had qualified audits and that the department had made further inquiry in relation to that. For the detail that Senator Carr is seeking, I need to take that on notice.

âI have, of course, asked questions about these matters in the past, and I was advised that, as of 25 August, only three responses to the department's overtures had been received from those 26 companiesâmany of which operate with multiple company or trading names, so it is obviously more than just the 26 colleges identified by these reports. As of today, how many are in breach of the reporting requirement? How many responses have been received by the department and how many remain overdue? I understand that 14 days is provided to the colleges to respond. Quite clearly, we are well in excess of that 14-day requirement, in some cases by many weeks. I ask the minister to take that matter on notice, and I expect that he will. Is that the case, Minister? Will you take that on notice?
âYes.
âWhen was the last time that the department undertook a random audit rather than rely on the 30 June cut-off point?
âI will take that on notice as well.
âI ask the minister: what action does the depart ment currently take to ensure compliance with attendance requirements of the ESOS Act?

âThere is an annual compliance test that the department carries out in relation to the various providers. There are a number of other matters which the department undertakes. I do not have that detail to hand, but I can provide that to Senator Carr fairly soon, I would imagine.

âDoes the department of education undertake random attendance checks of students' attendance? I mean by that: not notifying the particular college with 48 hours notice that they are intending to arrive and not counting chairs but counting students. I ask the minister: when was the last time such action was undertaken?
âAgain, I will have to take that on notice.

âIs it the case that there are considerable existing powers under the ESOS Act to prevent breaches of the ESOS Act? Given that the minister has announced a review with terms of reference substantially stronger than those originally announced when he first indicated his intention to move in this directionâwhich just so happened to coincide with a number of issues being pursued by the Labor Party on these mattersâare there existing powers that can be used to prevent the operations of fraudulent practitioners in this industry rather than wait for the inquiry to bring down a finding in the middle of next year?
âAny providers found to be in breach of the act can be suspended, as I understand itâwhich is a salutary sanction, I would suggest.

âI come back to the point that, given there have been no prosecutions in the last year and there is some question as to whether or not there have been any in recent years, what action has the government undertaken using its existing powers to clean up this industry?

âThe fact that there has been no prosecution does not necessarily mean that there has been some tardiness or negligence in relation to the department in carrying out its investigations. Senator Carr would agree, I am sure, that if any prosecution was to be brought it would be founded on evidence and proper procedure. If we rushed into any prosecution which was ill founded, no doubt Senator Carr would be the first to raise a complaint. We are engaging in due process in relation to these matters. I do not think that there can be any conclusions drawn from the fact that there has not been any prosecution in relation to the matters raised by Senator Carr.

âThe last I would be accusing this government of is rushing into anything in terms of seeking to improve the protection of the quality and integrity of this industry. Despite the fact that numerous complaints have been raised, despite the fact that I initiated an inquiry into the operations of this act last year and despite the fact that the Senate report was brought down on a unanimous basis, it is apparent that the government took over 12 months to move any further and only after a number of colleges had been named which had clearly been in breach of the law and which clearly had been identified by the department's own officers. For instance, I cite the case of the Business Institute of Victoria which collapsed in May this year, yet no action has been taken. The last thing I would be doing is accusing this government of rushing to actually do anything to improve the operations of this industry rather than have another inquiry.

speech.para: Dr Kemp has this tremendous technique. He gets a huge mirror out. When he has a problem or he has a complaint from the Labor Party, he gets a big mirror out and has a good look into it. That is all that ever happens. What you identify is a constant failure by this government to deal with fundamental questions which go to the heart of the success of education in this countryâthat is, provision of quality services. We have been seeing a decline in a range of areas. The minister acknowledges it himself these days. His cabinet submission said, `There is a perception of a decline in quality in higher education.' But we notice that it is not just in the universities. There is a decline in quality in a range of other educational institutions, yet there is no action being taken by this government other than to get the big mirror out and have a look into it.

Of course, when you find out what the scam really isâthat is, what the government's proposals really are in terms of their cabinet submissionâwe hear repeated denials: `Oh, we didn't really intend to do that at all. We didn't really want to get into that area at all.' We hear from the government: `That's not our intentionâto introduce an American style education system. We are not going to introduce a series of measures which would undermine the quality of education still further.' What we hear from this government is: `Well, we'll put that on the back burner. We'll have a look at that later on.' That is a pattern that is now emerging.

I ask the government: given that there are substantive powers currently available for this government to get off its tail and actually do something rather than get the mirror out, why isn't the government moving? What is stopping the government from moving? Of course, it will be said that it is natural justice. Well, there is no natural justice for the people that are ripped off by these unethical operators. There is no natural justice for those that are brought into this country as students and told that they are going to be given a quality education but find themselves forced into the clutches of some of these unsavoury characters. There is no natural justice for those that are used as cheap labour in the restaurants, the hotels, the cleaning businesses or the brothels in this country. There is no natural justice for them because they are here on the basis that if they do not do what they are told they will be shipped out. They are told, `Carry a toothbrush with you, because at any time you could be tapped on the shoulder and taken out.' There is no basis of complaint for them. There is no natural justice for them. There is only the opportunity to be given short shrift if you complain. There is therefore a continuing cycle of corruptionâcorruption in the sense that people act on the basis of monetary gain rather than the provision of the services which we would expect of them.

What has this got to do with education? It has everything to do with the quality of education. The provision of educational services in this country has to be predicated on the assumption that everyone is entitled to a high quality service. Increasingly evidence is showing that if we get a reputation internationally for not being able to provide a high quality service for everybody and we get a reputation for being used as the vehicle for various people smugglers then we will find that there will be a decline in our international reputation. That all comes back to the government. It comes back to the officers in this chamber at the moment because it is their responsibility as the gatekeepers on behalf of this parliament to ensure that we are providing a quality service. If they cannot do their job, we are entitled to ask: why not?

They say to people in the industry, `We do not have enough resources.' I say that is because the government has cut these officers back. There is 50 per cent less of them. I also say that the government does not have the political will to do anything about it. This government works on the assumption that the private marketâthe free-for-allâshould rule. That means that the lowest common denominator should rule. Cost pressures are leading to a decline in the number of students in many sectors, not just the universities but in so many other sectors of the international education industry. This bill goes to all of those, not just the higher education system. Cost pressures mean that providers are often placed in a position where they have to cut corners.

And when you have to compete against some of these characters that are offering courses for about $1,000 a year when the quality programs are running at $12,000 a year, you are entitled to ask: how do they do it? They do it on the basis that they are not actually teaching. They are not in the business of providing a service; they are in the business of providing a visa. That visa is then used to provide the sweatshops of this country with cheap labour. They are using vehicles such as the ESOS Act which is being subverted because this government is not doing enough to stop it. The providers who are engaged in this with crook immigration agents and crook education agents know what the scam is and know that they will not meet any real resistance from this government. That is a very serious question which goes to the very heart of the provision of education in this country and to the very heart of the nature of the matters being discussed before us at the moment. I ask again, minister: why are you not taking action, using the existing powers, to clean up the corrupt practices in this industry?

talk.start.para: âI can only reiterate that the department is looking into these matters, and that it would be unwise to comment on operational matters. Senator Carr knows that any inadvertent comment from me could well result in those who might be guilty escaping from proper investigation, and I am not about to do that, as I am not about to pre-empt any finding of the same. There is an investigation process; due process has to take its course. I reject entirely the allegation of Senator Carr that we are not pursuing these matters.
âMinister, there is one issue that does need clarification. Senator Stott Despoja sought to table a second document. I want to clarify whether leave is granted for that document to be tabled.

âI have had a chance to have a quick look at this document. The thing that strikes me is that at the bottom of the document it states, `This document has been retyped from the original.' I had understood, when Senator Stott Despoja was talking of this document, that we were dealing with a document which purported to be a cabinet submission and not a copy or retyping thereof. What we are talking about is two very different documents.

speech.para: What we would be doing here, were we to allow this to go forward in its self-proclamation as a cabinet submission, would be to rely on an anonymous person who has retyped this document and to rely on that person as having: (a) retyped this from a cabinet submission; and (b) done so accurately. Without knowing who did that and the circumstances and without knowing about the original document, no Australian government would ever agree to the tabling of such a document.

This could be the greatest fraud of all timeâI am not to knowâbecause we have at the bottom of each page, `This document has been retyped from the original,' not copied but retyped. It could have been reframed, reworded. We do not know the identity of the person who sat down and retyped it. We do not know what the original document looked like. We have nothing which identifies the original here. There is no copy number on this submission. So I reject entirely that this document is what it says it is. On that basis, the government refuses leave.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for his explanation of why the government will be denying leave for the purposes of tabling this document. It is not unusual for documents that are controversial or that may be disagreed with by the government, or even the opposition of the day, to be tabled as a matter of courtesy. I have made available to the chamberâwith the acceptance and willingness of the opposition, in particular the opposition whipâthis document which I have quoted from and which has been the subject of debate while we have been discussing this bill. So it is actually quite appropriate that this document, regardless of whether or not it is the original, should be tabled. I think it should be tabled.

speech.para: I acknowledge that the government has denied leave in a show of what I believe is a lack of goodwill. I believe the minister today has gone much further than Dr David Kemp in relation to this document, first of all mentioning hearsay, now questioning whether or notâit is a reasonable question to askâthe content has differed in any way. I bet that if it had Dr David Kemp would have issued an all points bulletin. We would have had an alert telling us exactly what bits were fraudulent or incorrect or inappropriate in some way.

Quite the contrary: we have heard Dr Kemp in a number of instances, in particular in an interview with Kerry O'Brien on the 7.30 ReportâI thank the minister for granting leave to table that documentâexpressly acknowledging quotes from that document, not resiling from them, not suggesting that he is not responsible. He does not resile or recoil from them in any way. He counters them on some occasions with perhaps different arguments or interpretations. But I did not read one sentence that said, `This is not my document, I did not write this.' Quite the contrary: a number of his statements began, `I was not saying this there' or `I said this' or `We meant in the document that'. Excuse my paraphrasing. He does not resile from the ownership of that document.

I thank the minister for his concerns. I am a little upset by his lack of goodwill. I think there is a good argument to table a document when there have been a number of quotations from that document, and the government can put on record its concerns about that document being tabled. No-one is pretending that it is the original. When you table a document that says, `This document has been retyped from the original', you are not exactly pretending. It is an interesting argument that the minister has put forward but a little churlish. I suspect that David Kemp might have a slightly different attitude. I take the minister at his word when he says that he had not seen it until today, although the rest of us involved in education debates had seen it.

talk.start.para: âI stress once again that what we are relying on here, with the retyping or reconstruction of this document, is that a third party has been involved in that. That third party, via this document, is trying to tell the Senate, if this were to be tabled, what the original said. That is hearsay. It is hearsay per se.

speech.para: I also say that Dr Kemp might have referred to one or two quotes that were mentioned. That is not an adoption of the entire document. That document is a rather lengthy one. It would be entirely improper to assume from that interview which took place that Dr Kemp had adopted this document. Indeed, he did not. It was not put to him by the interviewer at the time that he read through it and adopt it. You cannot play fast and loose with laws of evidence; you cannot play fast and loose with procedural fairness.

Because someone has adopted a quote or referred to a document does not mean that the document which it was attempted to table today has been adopted by the minister concerned. That does not follow. In relation to the fact that this document is retyped, perhaps the opposition and the Democrats could be more genuine and put to the Senate the original, and not some reconstruction about which we have no assurance and which might be a fraud.

talk.start.para: âWelcome to the chair, Senator Lightfoot; I am sure you will enjoy this. I indicate to the ministerâI do not think I have made it clearâthat I have asked the government to investigate a number of colleges that I have named in regard to overseas students. I accept the minister's assurance that they will be investigated. I also acknowledge that an allegation is not in itself evidence of guilt. However, I do requireâand I will be pursuing the departmental officers on this issue at the estimates hearings on 1 Decemberâthat there be a robust inquiry into the operations of those colleges to date. I reiterate that claims have been made to me by numerous participants in the industry. It is consistent across the country that these complaints are being made, so I do take the view that they have considerable validity. Many of these types of complaints have been put to the department on previous occasions and have not been investigated. So I will want to follow up those matters in the next round of estimates.

speech.para: There are a number of new issues. I do not want to suggest that all matters that I am pursuing have been previously raised, but I have raised a number of new examples. I expect the department may not have had knowledge of them, although I would be surprised, if the department were seriously engaged with this industry, if the department were not aware of the information that has been provided.

I turn now to the issue of Greenwich University, which is another institution that I have raised concerns about. I have raised concerns about a range of institutions, that is, those operating in this new twilight zone of the Internet. I have mentioned the Australasian Institute. I have raised the issue of the University of Asia and St Clements. I have been concerned at the failure of this government to take a whole-of-government approach to the question of these universities operating outside of the HEFA Act, with the exception, presumably now, of Greenwich. They claim to be Australian universities, and operate in the international market as Australian universities, to which the government seems to have a range of responses according to whether it is the taxation department, the securities commission, the department of education, the department of territories or the department of immigration. I ask the minister: has the government developed a whole-of-government approach to the question of these Internet universities?

talk.start.para: âWe have a review well under way in relation to the Greenwich University.
âAnother one?

âNo, this is the one that was originally being conducted by a panel established by the Commonwealth and one which Senator Carr is well aware of. We are waiting for further information to be provided by Greenwich University. It would be premature for the government to set up any whole-of-government approach to `Internet universities', as he puts them, without first ascertaining the result of this inquiry. It might be jumping the gun, as it were, if we were to pre-empt our inquiry and go off half-cocked with a whole-of-government approach. This inquiry is well under way and no doubt as a result of it the government will be looking at how it does things in the future.

âMinister, we have yet another example of the mirror approach to education policy by this government. We have another good look into something and we get a series of scandals exposed. We have a body claiming to be a university in South Australia operating out of the back of a grog shop, we have another one in Queensland operating out of a post office box, and we have these clowns in Greenwich, in Norfolk Island. In Victoria some of these universities are claiming to be in association with established reputable universities. Yet the government does nothing about it.

speech.para: What the government does without its whole-of-government approach is to allow the Department of the Treasury to have a different view and encourages them. Some of these people get export awards. That is what I find staggering. Some of these bogus operations get rewarded by this government because we do not have a whole-of-government approach to international education. You have the Department of the Treasury saying: `It is okay if you want to operate in this field. Anyone can call themselves a university.' I have a company around the corner from my electoral office known as University Meats. I would expect under this government's policy that they should be able to operate as a university, because that is the way it is functioning at the moment. We do not have a whole-of-government approach. The left hand has no idea what the right hand is doing.

The minister today has indicated to us that that appears to be government policy because it does not want to pre-empt anything. It would only be natural justice for every crook who wants to plunder this country to do so! That is natural justice! You will be able to call yourself a university. You will have freedom of choice. You can operate out of a grog shop and call yourself a university. You can operate out of an offshore island. You can get the local council to hoodwink a minister who would not know one end of a university from another to direct the Administrator of Norfolk Island to establish a university on that island and then claim that it has access to Australia's reputation as a quality provider.

I come back to this point. When will the Gallagher report come down? It was initiated by the Commonwealth, true, but only after we again pursued the question. When will we have an indication of what the department and the officers associated with this committee are able to claim is their response to the question of the bona fides of Greenwich University?

talk.start.para: âI cannot add anything further. Any investigation has a life of its own; it is an island unto itself. I cannot say on what date that investigation will be completed. It would be wrong of me to say soâwhen Senator Carr asks when this report is due. He knows very well that I cannot pre-empt the date.
âMinister, I had the good fortune to read Campus Review just a couple of weeks ago. It was able to detail a draft report outlining certain criteria for accreditation.
âHearsay.

âThe minister interjects and says that it is hearsay. The report of the Campus Review some weeks ago detailed what was purported to be a draft of the criteria for accreditation for these new universities. Was the document that they reproduced an accurate document? Did it reflect the committee's thinking at that time?

âSenator Carr is asking us to accept what Campus Review has said. I have not seen that article, but it purports to convey to the community at large a draft report which is the product of the Gallagher committeeâas Senator Carr puts it. I am not about to say whether or not that is true or untrue. All I do know is that that committee is carrying out its inquiries and that for me to comment on the result of those inquiries one way or another would be improper. The publication concerned might be careful in relation to how it reports that report. I am not about to comment on the authenticity of its report or otherwise.

âI note that the government is allowing these operators to continue, despite the fact that there is no formal accreditation process in place to deal with these private providers of dubious providence. Is it the case that the government has plans to allow them access to public funding for both teaching and research?
âI will take that question on notice.

âWhen will the minister be able to respond to that question? He has taken it on notice. Does that mean the normal 28-day provision? Do we have to follow through the normal operations of the standing orders for questions on notice? Would the minister accept that at this point?

âNot all of the matters that Senator Carr has raised at the committee stage have been pertinent to the funding covered by this particular bill. This is a higher education funding amendment bill. I concede that, in its title, it is broad in application. However, not everything that Senator Carr has asked today has been entirely specific to the billâsome have, some have notâand not all the officials from the department have been present for this debate. There are also detailed questions that Senator Carr has put to us and we will look into them. The government has a fairly good record on education and on answering questionsâvoluminous as they are from Senator Carr. We still do our best to answer those queries.

âMinister, I say to you that the questions I have asked are directly related to the bill insofar as this bill sets maximum funding levels for the expenditure on international marketing and promotion of Australian education and training services by Australian Education International for the 2001 funding year. That is the case, Minister, is it not? This is directly related to the operations of this bill. This is the international division of the department that is directly covered by this bill.
âThe administration of the ESOS Act is not in this bill. It's irrelevant.

âNo, Minister, you are dead wrong. The officers in the international education division of the department of employment administer the ESOS Act. This goes specifically to the issue of the marketing and promotion of Australian education and training services by Australian Education International. You are dead wrong on that, Minister. I am asking you a specific question. You have taken a number of questions on notice today. You have said to me that you will come back with answers. I understand that you may not have the detail available immediately. My question relates to when you will reply and whether the normal provisions of the standing orders, as far as you are concerned, cover such questions on notice.

âI can tell Senator Carr that we will do our best to get the answers to him. However, I take issue with the fact that the ESOS Act, and the administration thereof, has formed the basis of several questions from Senator Carr. The ESOS Act, or any amending bill to it, is not before us. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill is before us. Some of the officers from the international division might be here, but it is not a matter which is before the chamber as such. The ESOS Act is something quite separate. It relates to higher education, but it is a discrete area. We will endeavour to answer those questions which have been taken on notice as quickly as possible.

âI repeat, Minister, that Australian Education International covers all aspects of international education, including the administration of the ESOS Act. This is expenditure for this division of the department which, as part of its responsibilities, administers the ESOS Act. I take your point about answering the questions. Unfortunately, I must advise you that, notwithstanding your good faith, far too often I have had occasion to raise with this department its failure to answer questions and to answer them in their entirety. I will be pursuing these matters if you are not able to get the department to respond in the spirit in which you have spoken in the chamber today. I ask the minister: when will the government announce its formal policy on accreditation of private and Internet higher education providers in general?

âI do not think that I can add to that; we have gone over this previously. The inquiry into the Greenwich University is a key factor in all of this and, as I have said, I am unable to give any indication to the Senate as to when that would conclude and, even if I could, it would be improper of me to do so.
âI just want to be clear about this. Is it the government's intention to use a voucher scheme for private or Internet providers in terms of access to any funds from the public purse?
âI will take that question on notice.

speech.para: Request agreed to.
Bill agreed to, with a request.
Bill reported with a request; report adopted.

subdebateinfo.title: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 18 October.
Motion (by Senator Ellison) proposed:
That the committee does not insist on its amendments to which the House of Representatives has disagreed and agrees to the additional amendment made by the House of Representatives to the bill.

talk.start.para: âLet me outline the position of the opposition. We will be opposing the government's motion. Therefore, we will be voting to insist that the amendments carried by the Senate when the bill was dealt with a month or two ago should stand. The government in the House of Representatives has moved, and it was carried, an amendment which would establish a Forest Products Advisory Council. That is the amendment that Minister Ellison referred to a moment ago. Our position is that we believe that the amendments that we originally moved in the Senate but which were not carriedâto establish a Wood and Paper Industry Councilâare more appropriate and, accordingly, we will be moving an amendment to once again put that to the Senate. That amendment, I understand, has been circulated and is set out on sheet 1617.

speech.para: To summarise our position, we will oppose the government's motion insofar as it relates to not insisting upon the Senate's amendments previously carried. In relation to the government's proposal for a Forest Products Industry Council, we will move an amendment that would establish a Wood and Paper Industry Council. If that amendment is not carried by the Senateâbut we hope that on this occasion the Democrats will reconsider their position and support itâthen we would, rather reluctantly, ultimately support the government's proposal. Although we believe it is a long way short of the desirable outcome, it is nevertheless better than nothing. I hope that is clear. That may therefore require the vote to be taken separately, although we are happy to have the issues treated together.

talk.start.para: âIn the light of your comments, can I confirm that you would now like the question to be divided?

âYes, thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I note also that Senator Brown has circulated two amendments to be moved in addition to the amendment that has been carried by the House of Representatives, namely, the amendment establishing a Forest Products Advisory Council. I will indicate our attitude to Senator Brown's amendments at the appropriate time.

speech.para: I will now make some remarks in regard to the government's refusal to consider any of the amendments that were carried by this Senate. I remind the government and senators generally that this debate spanned six days. It was lengthy and detailed, and there is no doubt that a lot of attention was given to the important issues by the Senate at that time. Further, this is a matter that has been widely canvassed for quite some time. We are therefore very disappointed at the way in which Minister Tucker flippantly treats the very considered amendments carried by this chamber. His response publicly after the Senate carried the legislation with those amendments was, in his usual bullying fashion, to try and stand up the Senate and the parliament and say that he would consider withdrawing the legislation. His attitude was that these amendments would not be given any serious con sideration at all by him or the government. His message to the Senate was, `You had better pass my bill, or else.' That is reflective of his attitude all the way through the development of this legislation.

When he came to deal with the bill last week in the other place, he demonstrated his hypocritical and inconsistent approach; and he demonstrated that his approach is a political one, not one that is based on a balanced approach and a balanced assessment looking for a balanced outcome in a very difficult issue. For instance, he rejected our perfectly reasonable objects clause, yet in his opening remarks in the debate in the other place last week he stated:

The Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 provides legislative support to the outcomes being achieved under the regional forest agreement process. The government is working cooperatively with the states to implement the National Forest Policy Statement, which is the framework for a long-term and lasting resolution of forest industry, conservation and community interests and expectations concerning our nation's forests.

So at the very outset he acknowledges the importance of the principles of the National Forest Policy Statement, but he point blank refuses to even include in the bill an objects clause that will reflect the principles of that statement.

Subsequently, however, in his own amendment establishing the Forest Products Industry Council, in what is clearly a political move designed to win over some support from the union movement for his proposals, he has agreed to include recognition of the wood and paper industry strategy. It is rather ironic, because the wood and paper industry strategy was one developed by the previous Labor government as a consequence of the principles of the National Forest Policy Statement. That was a strategy that was abandoned by this government when it came to office, but now this minister, in a rather cynical way, is prepared to give recognition to that in his half-baked proposal for a Forest Products Advisory Council. It is clearly inconsistent. Why on the one hand object to a perfectly reasonable, sensible and necessary objects clause but on the other hand in another amendment give some recognition to it? I will come back to the Forest Products Industry Council and our proposal for the Wood and Paper Industry Council a little later.

The minister has also gone around the country in his usual fashion attacking the Labor Party and attacking the Senate, claiming that we are frustrating the process. He is now claiming that somehow, as a result of this legislation not being passed, all RFAs will not be completed by 31 December this year. The delays are due entirely to this minister. If one has followed his performance over past months, one can see him chop and change from day to day or week to week. One day he is attacking the industry and the New South Wales government for their agreement on the north coast forests, trying to play the role of an environmentalist. The next day he is attacking the Western Australian government. There is absolutely no consistency in his approach, and that has been demonstrated by his reaction to the amendments put forward by the Senate.

I turn quickly to one other issue. No doubt I will need to make some further remarks on it later in this committee consideration. The minister has claimed, in his reasons for rejecting our proposal for disallowance procedures, that they are unconstitutional. It is quite clear that his arguments just give support to the old maxim that you can get whatever legal advice you want if you frame the question accordingly. In what has to be one of the greatest jokes of all time from this minister, he says that we do not need a disallowance process or a parliamentary scrutiny process. I quote from his reasons:
Further, if there is a concern that RFA requirements are not being complied with, it is open to parliament to amend or repeal the bill.

This is a bill that, when enacted, is supposed to give certainty to this industry. Yet this minister says he will not accept parliamentary scrutiny at the outset of the process but that, if there is a problem somewhere over the next 20 years, the parliament can come back and amend the legislation. That is a nonsensical proposition and a dangerous proposition for this industry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Greens will not be voting for the House of Representatives resolution that we should drop the amendments that the Senate put to the House. Even with those amendments, the forest industry gets lay down misere through this regional forest agreements legislation. I will remind the committee that this legislation is basically a corroboration of the regional forest agreements whereby the Prime Minister has signed away the powers and responsibilities of the federal parliament to the states and the woodchip corporations over Australia's native forests for the next 20 years. In particular, the legislation provides that, where the forestsâor the wildlife in themâare to be protected by federal decree in those 20 years, the woodchip corporations are to be compensated by Australian taxpayers for the value of those forests for which the woodchip corporations have never paid a red centânothing at all. What has astounded me about this whole process is that those very woodchip corporations have cried crocodile tears over jobs in the forests right down the line and yet there is no provision in the legislation and no move by the House of Representativesâthat is, the governmentâin this process to provide for compensation for workers who lose their jobs, not even for the reskilling of them.

speech.para: This is a heist of the Australian people's forests for a small number of rich corporations to maraud the unprotected forests of this nation, largely to send those forests as woodchips to Japan, Korea, China and other destinations in the Northern Hemisphere where they are converted into paper and enter the disposal cycle. The grandest forests of this country end up in the landfills of the Northern Hemisphere, and where the forests are destroyed the wildlife is destroyed with them.

As I have explained to the Senate in the previous full debate on this matter, the cycle in Tasmania is to cut down the grand forests, firebomb to prevent any regrowth of rainforest or competing species, and then poison the area with 1080 to kill any wildlife coming into the area. And this legislation is to compensate that process, augment it, foster it and extend it. As you will remember, Mr Temporary Chairman Lightfoot, during this debate when I asked the government representative aboutâand challenged that representative overâso-called ecologically sustainable logging that this legislation is supposed to foster, she sat glued to her seat because there is no defence of the doublespeak.

Ecologically sustainable logging, according to Prime Minister Howard's pacts with several premiers, means total destruction of the forests and their replacement with genetically modified, fast growing eucalypts or pines for the further enhancement of the woodchip corporations' interests further down the line. All this is totally unnecessary because, as you know, there are enough plantations in this country to provide all its wood needs.

Even when it comes to the balance of payments, the myth that is put about by peopleâincluding the government spokesperson on forests and so-called conservation, Mr Tuckeyâis that we are somehow imbalanced in a way which requires us to continue the destruction of our native forests. In fact, we export twice as much wood as we import. The problem is that the industry, because it is rapacious and greedy, does not downstream process in this country or create the jobs here. It allows that to happen elsewhere and we import goods based on wood at twice the cost that we export our wood. So we end up basically with this terrible process where we export much more than we bring into the country, but we pay more for what we bring into the country than what we export. There is nothing in this legislation or in the amendments coming back from the House of Representatives that is going to meet that problem and get Australia the advantage that it could have through downstream processing of its plantations, protection of its native forests and a commitment by the industry, as well as government, to look after the jobs of those in the forests.

The regional forest agreement signed in Tasmania is a fraud. It is a fraud that has been perpetrated on the workers in the industry. Those Tasmanian senators who are present will have read the weekend press in Tasmania which highlighted a group of transport operators committed to the logging industry. They talked about how they had come to this parliament to protest against conservationists and in favour of the wood chipping industry but in the last few weeks, in the wake of the regional forest agreement whereby Prime Minister Howard and others indicated that they were acting in the `interests of the workers', they have been dumped. They have huge repayments on their machinery and they have no way of paying them. Some of those men and their families are going to end up in bankruptcy.

Where is the logging industry? Where is the government? Where is the Bacon Labor government in Tasmania, which supports this fraudulent process? Where is the Prime Minister to succour these people who have now been put on the garbage tip and have been thrown out of work, along with nearly 500 others who have suffered a similar fate, since the woodchip organisations managed to get the Prime Minister's and the Premier's signatures on the bottom of a regional forest agreement? Then we are asked in this Senate to endorse that process.

The sad thing about this is that even the Labor Party's amendments left Tasmania out in the cold. There is no review process in these proposals either from the House of Representatives or from the Senate to enable the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement to be vetted by the Senate. We are supposed to accept, as a parliament, a mechanism whereby the Prime Minister and the state Premier have signed an agreement to hand across the forests to the sectional interests of the big corporations who are not based in Tasmaniaâneither their headquarters nor their shareholders areâbut at the same time to underwrite them should there be any future federal move on behalf of the nation or Tasmanians in particular to protect our forests. The whole process is shameful. It is disgusting.

Nevertheless, I am hopeful that these minimalist amendments which the Senate agreed to will be insisted upon. How dare the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, who has conserved nothing since he entered that portfolio, rail against the Senate for these minimalist amendments which, amongst other things, would see the regional forest agreements on the mainland, with the exception of the early agreements signed in East Gippsland and in Victoria, brought before the parlia ment. The taxpayers are underwriting them; should not the parliament be vetting them? Of course it should. As a Green I will be supporting these amendments for the little improvement that they do make to what is a parlous sell-out of the nation's interest, which the regional forest agreement process and this legislation represent.

I have to foreshadow that I will be moving amendments to the amendment brought up here from the House of Representatives so that if there isâand this is another gift to the industryâa forest products, taxpayer funded council set up, it is not just those who wield chainsaws that are on the council but also representatives from the forest related tourism industry, because that is where the job creation in forests is in Tasmania. There are more people getting jobs out of the preservation of our forests, intact, in Tasmaniaâmore than 3,000 these daysâthan are involved in the destruction of native forests.

I will also be moving an amendment to say that there should be represented on such an industry council people who are interested in forest related water industries, because there has been a lot of contention not only in this country but also right around the world about the damage to water catchments that accrues from loggingâand not just through the pollution of streams by direct run-off and by soiling of streams. I remember an indigenous person in Sarawak describing their river, which used to be pristine and full of fish but now was neither, as looking like a river of Miloâreferring to the Nestle productâbecause that is just what their river looked like. Rivers in Australia downstream of logging operations look much the same.

Of course, there is the added hazard after the logging industry has moved in of the spraying of pesticides and, on occasions, herbicides into the fast growing plantations. These are particularly vulnerable, genetically modified plantations which replace these forests very often in the headwaters of rivers which are used for a variety of other purposes, including drinking water for people living downstream. Water is an industry these days and that very important commercial as well as environmental entity should be represented on any such council.

Earlier I supported the proposal put forward by the Labor Party as an alternative, which I think is superior, and I would make a minor amendment to ensure that a representative of the Australian Conservation Foundation is on the council that is proposed there. I support the Senate's stand on this matter. I hope that the Senate will remain resolute. I take the opportunity again to condemn the legislation while adding support to these very minor, around the edges amendments which the Senate has made and put to the House of Representatives and which the House of Representatives is, in the interests of the woodchip corporations, trying to eliminate.

talk.start.para: âThe reasons why the government does not support these amendments and in particular the amendments which tie regional forest agreements to a new objects clause, thus enabling disallowance by either house, have already been explained to the Senate in the previous debate and I do not propose to go over those matters again. I would, however, like to take a few moments to explain to the opposition the practical consequences of their disallowance proposal. This amendment would require that proposed RFAs be tabled in each house, and each house then has 15 sitting days to disallow. This is to be preceded by certain procedural requirements, including publication of the proposed RFA in the gazette, and it includes the RFAs signed in Western Australia, north-east Victoria and Eden.

speech.para: It is highly probable that there would be an attempt to disallow all these RFAs in the Senate, and the opposition itself has implied that it will seek to disallow the Western Australian RFA. Given that the remaining uncompleted RFAs are not likely to be signed before mid-December at the earliest, the consequence of the opposition's amendments would be the immediate cessation of woodchip processing in all areas except those where RFAs were signed before 1 March 1999, because the exporters would have no guarantee that their product could be shipped. The parliamentary sitting schedule means that this would be the case even if the government were to move to extend the existing licences for a short period and regardless of whether or not the RFAs were eventually disallowed by the Senate. The mere fact that Senate approval was required would prevent a woodchip exporter from processing residues.

For those RFAs disallowed by the Senate there would be no certainty of a final resolution at all, given the need to negotiate sequentially with the states and the Senate. No doubt the Greens and the Democrats would be very pleased with this outcome, but it would cause massive disruption to the native hardwood timber industry in Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and possibly even Tasmania. Timber mills would either close or lay off workers, and contractors would be unemployed. These impacts would hit hardest in small mills where sales of residue play a larger part in cash flow. There are no circumstances under which the government would allow this to happen and therefore it cannot support the amendments. I am surprised, Senator Murphy, that you are supporting these amendments, given your usual stand on the rights of the workers and the way in which you want to support industries in Tasmania, because your state will be hit hardest by these.

talk.start.para: âYou will hear from me in due course.

âThere would also need to be a freeze on industry development and restructuring assistance negotiated as part of RFAs, further penalising industry and stifling investment prospects. Industry has pushed the need for RFA-led certainty legislation, and it has strongly expressed the view that it would be more secure without the bill rather than have an amended bill as proposed which would deliver additional uncertainty. Therefore, the only thing that these amendments are achieving is delaying the bill until after all the RFAs are signed and preventing the government from getting on with the job of restructuring the industry under secure RFA regimes. After all the RFAs are signed, the effect of the amendments would be to prevent almost all woodchip exports for a period ranging from some months to indefinitelyâa position which I am assuming the opposition will not promote.

speech.para: As we all know, the government has previously tabled advice from the Office of General Counsel that the parliamentary scrutiny provisions proposed by the opposition are unconstitutional. I note that the shadow minister for justice argued against this view in the other place and raised some interesting legal issues. However, at the end of the day, an argument about whose legal advice is better will not matter one whit.

The real vote on this bill will be taken by those people who are contemplating major investment in this industry which, I remind the Senate, currently runs an annual trade deficit of almost $2 billion. Those people are telling us that they will not invest without the security provided by this bill as originally put forward by the government. So the choice is now with the opposition.

Senator Forshaw, you mentioned that you were disappointed. I am also disappointed with the attitude of the opposition. You can either support the government in not insisting on these amendments or you can again support the amendments which I have clearly explained to you would cause unemployment among the very people whom you claim to represent. You would also cause massive disruption to an industry which you purport to support. The choice is yours.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: âI now call on consideration of government documents. There are 48 government documents for consideration on today's Order of Business and a limit of 30 minutes for their consideration. To expedite the consideration of documents I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of five. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will not be listed on the Notice Paper , and documents not called on today will be listed on the Notice Paper . There being no objection it is so ordered.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the documents.

Documents Nos 22 and 23 deal with the way our companies are regulated in Australia. These reports come out of Treasury. They used to come out of the Attorney-General's Department but, in recent years, corporations have been regulated through the Treasury because the government wants to give emphasis to the function of companies involved in producing goods and services so that the country can become more wealthy, and that is a good thing. But companies are not simply about that. There are other aspects of them that should be looked at. These two reports are interesting in their contrasts. The first is a report from the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. That is a committee dedicated to enabling company law to be so arranged as to give companies the ability to flourish as they should. They have much to do with matters like CLERP.

The other report is from the Australian Securities and Investments Commission. It also deals with the sorts of things that the first report deals with. In addition, it points out the other issues that are very much alive in the corporate world. On page 33 of the report, the Chairman, Mr Alan Cameron, notes that, during the period that this report covers, `$6.5 million was recovered for miners who worked at Cobar. An amount of 87 cents in the dollar was recovered for those people.' Unfortunately, there is no mention here of other areas where workers have been left without their due rewardâareas like Mount Schank, Wodonga and others which have now become famous.

What this report does is to indicate that companies now affect the lives of all of usânot only our working lives but also the lives that we may lead in terms of leisure. Companies affect the environment. There is now a provision in the Corporations Law requiring companies to give an account of how they have looked to the care of the environment during the course of a particular reporting period. That is important to understand: companies are now so fundamental to the sorts of lives that we all live that it is time this parliament became more and more conscious of that fact and made laws that require companies not only to produce the income and wealth they do but also to act in a way that is consistent with the sort of life that we all want to lead. We have dealt with the way that powerful interests have acted in the past, and it is now time for us to look at companiesânot only multinational companies but companies generallyâto see them for what they are and to make our laws so that not only the economy is looked to but also every other aspect of our lives.
