talk.start.para: âI put the question that the documents be accepted.

âI am advised that we need to put the question with respect to Senator Cooney's documents first, Senator Brown. I now put the question that Senator Cooney's documents be accepted.

subdebateinfo.title: Director of National Parks and Wildlife

talk.start.para: âI refer to the document listed at No. 13, which is in relation to the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and, indeed, another document tabled today which is to do with the reasons for delaying the report on the finances of the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. The question that I want to canvass here, and it is a question I am putting to the government, particularly to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, goes to a report in the Australian on Tuesday, 5 October.
âOrder! Senator Brown, would you be kind enough to say what number that document is.
âThe second document I am referring to; we have had notice of it today. It is the first one that was tabled by the Clerk today.
âDocuments Nos 1 to 16, I think, have already been accepted.

âI refer to the first document that was tabled today by the Clerk. It is called the Acts Interpretation ActâStatement pursuant to subsection 34C(6) relating to the extension of specified period for presentation of a reportâDirector of National Parks and Wildlife Report for 1998-99. So I am relating to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife report for 1998-99.
âSenator Brown, that has no relevance to these particular documents that we are accepting.
âOkay.
âWe are not accepting; we are noting, I am informed.
âI will await, then, a full list of the documents. I will go back to a full list of the documents and continue my remarks when I get that.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Affirmative Action Agency is responsible for administering the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act 1986. The act covers all private sector organisations, higher education institutions, group training schemes, unions, community organisations and non-government schools with more than 100 employees.

The objective of the Affirmative Action Agency is to achieve equal employment status for women and to assist in the elimination of employment discrimination. I would like to draw to the Senate's attention what I believe to be one of the agency's most important roles: monitoring the actual progress of businesses in implementing affirmative action programs. It is good to know that businesses and other groups around Australia are starting to realise that it makes sense to treat women as equals and to promote programs that help women realise their full potential.

The agency acknowledges that reports made to it by various groups show incremental improvements to various practices. Nearly 300 organisations have been identified as best practice. There are, unfortunately, 55 organisations that have not met their reporting requirements under the act. I am not going to single out organisations that are identified as best practice, nor am I going to single out the ones that are non-compliant. I do want to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the best represented private sector companies in the annual report's list of best practice groups are machinery and equipment manufacturing companies and metal ore mining companies. Universities and a number of community groups are also listed. I congratulate the organisations in those areas, especially the equipment manufacturing and mining industries, that have made those achievements in a particularly difficult trading environment.

There are a lot of statistics in the annual report, but let me focus on one particular area that the agency looked at: recognising that women are more likely to be the primary caregiver to children is extremely important. Overall, 66 per cent of organisations look at workplace agreements and awards for their possible impact on women's conditions of employment. Private sector companies are becomingly increasingly aware of the need for this, with 71 per cent saying they looked at this in 1998. This was up from 65 per cent in 1997 and just 48 per cent in 1994.

The agency reports that `part-time work with pro-rata conditions continues to be an increasing feature of employment practice across all sectors, with almost 86 per cent of all organisations utilising part-time employment'. Unfortunately, the provision of paid maternity leave is widely disparate across the different sectors. The private sector, despite increases of one or two per cent in each of the last four years, still has maternity leave provision rates of less than 17 per centâless than one in five. Thankfully, the percentage of schools, higher education institutions and community groups providing this condition is much higher.

All of the sectors examined are increasingly implementing job-sharing. A total of 67 per cent of private sector companies are providing job sharing opportunities. That is up 23 per cent since 1994. All of these initiatives give women a better chance of pursuing a career and starting a family.

Let me finish by congratulating the staff of the Affirmative Action Agency for all they have achieved in promoting the role of women in the work force. I hope they continue their good work next year and beyond, especially in light of the proposed changes to the act under which they operate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I would like to acknowledge the work done by the Australian Political Exchange Council in sending young people from the four federal parliamentary parties to other countries to study the political systems in those countries. I was a beneficiary of one of the programs and I benefited greatly. I would like to mention that colleagues have also benefited from the study tours. Document No. 29 relates to the Employment Advocate of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. The annual report 1998-99 is, I hope, the penultimate report of the Office of the Employment Advocate. I am waiting expectantly for their final report next year.

Page 6 of the annual report contains a summary of the Employment Advocate's functions. They include providing assistance and advice to employers, especially in small business; advice to employees under the Workplace Relations Act 1996; and a number of other matters. It goes on to state that, in performing these functions, it will also:

pay special regard to the needs of workers in a disadvantaged bargaining position (for example, women, people from a non-English speaking background, young people, apprentices, trainees and outworkers).
The second area is `assisting workers to balance work and family responsibilities'.

Unfortunately, one's ability to make an assessment of the financial reporting regime of the Office of the Employment Advocate is a little hampered. At page 7, which covers the Employment Advocate's staff, we are told that the budget for the Employment Advocate will appear in the DEWRSB budget appropriationâwhich I understand is not yet tabled. But some insight is provided into the types of things that the Employment Advocate spends its money on. The report certainly does not provide any great detail on the matters I referred to earlier, but it does say that something in the order of $315,268 or 7.8 per cent of salaries is spent on training themselves. If you then multiply thatâmy figures might be a bit wrongâthe salary is $4 million odd.

It is interesting to look at the advertising the Office of the Employment Advocate has undertaken. Some $2.9 million was spent on campaign advertising. This involved the placement of advertisements in the media, the production of print and television advertisements and so on. It excludes its non-campaign matters, which total some $14,000 for the cost of newspaper advertisements. So the cost of the advertisements of this organisation are, in short, extraordinary. It then talks about matters that it does not really give figures on. It talks about market research by Brian Sweeney and Associates, who undertook some concept testing of advertisements suggested for their campaign. It does not give any figures on this. It talks about the Wallis research group, and does not provide any figures for this.

It then talks about 50-odd consultancies on which about $1.3 million was spent. The figures for advertisements, consultancies, market research and money it spent training its officers certainly mount up. Reference is made on page 22 to what it actually spent on delivering the services that I spoke about earlier. We are told that the budget for extending the pilot with the direct client services providers into the second half of 1998-99 was some $167,000.

From looking at the reporting for the second half of 1998-99, you can gain a slight appreciation that they spent $167,000 on delivering some of those services that they should be delivering. However, their advertising budget is nothing short of extraordinary. The results of that are even more extraordinary. During 1998-99 it approved some 39,874 AWAsâa pitiful amount. If you divide that by the $2.9 million for advertising, you are left with about $72 per head.

You then go to the cost of complaints. There were 785 complaints for the yearâan extraordinarily low amount. Divide that by the $2.9 million in advertising, and it comes to something in the order of $3,694.26âquite an extraordinary amount to be spending on that number of inquiries. The Commonwealth Ombudsman receives around 23,000 complaints. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSenator Ludwig has been somewhat critical of the matters set out in this report and I must confess I can understand why. This report is very sparse on the sort of information that would enable parliament to assess just how successful the Office of the Employment Advocate is and exactly what work it does. For example, on page 8, under the heading `Delivering quality management', the report states:

speech.para: The OEA has continued to outsource its internal audit function to KPMG. KPMG oversee a program of quarterly internal audit reviews.

There is no detail of that audit, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson. Somebody with the vast experience you have in this area would understand what an adequate audit is and what detail might be expected so that members of parliament and, indeed, anybody reading the report can understand just what the audit consists of and how effective it has been. On page 9, under the heading of `Fraud control', the report says:
The Employment Advocate has taken further steps to guarantee that fraud control remains a priority within the OEA. As part of this plan, the OEAâ
the Office of Employment Advocateâ
implemented a fraud control policy as a development from the existing fraud control plan.

It would have been useful for people reading this report to know why the Office of Employment Advocate should be so concerned about fraud within the Office of Employment Advocate and why it is giving priority to guarantee that fraud control remains in the forefront of its concerns. When the Employment Advocate comes to prepare the annual report for 1999-2000, perhaps he might give consideration to those issues.

It is difficult to understand what it is that the Employment Advocate does when he deals with cases. Pages 18, 19 and 20 illustrate what I mean. The Employment Advocate mentions an action he has against a Victorian employer. The number given is VG389 of 1998. It simply says:

A part XA matter re an employer in the leisure industry failing to re-engage casual employee who did not sign an AWA and complained to the OEA. The matter was settled on payment of compensation to the employee and undertakings from the employer.

From that you can get no concept of how the Employment Advocate went about his job, how effective he was, how adequate the compensation was and how effective the undertaking from the employer was going to be.

A series of other legal matters are referred to, mainly against unions. They are named. The employer is not named. The union is named and in each case an assessment is given of how the case is going. There seem to be a lot more actions against unions than against employers. It would be useful to know why that is the case and how the Employment Advocate is going about his job. This report raises a lot of questions but answers very few of them. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Banking Services

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to continue a series of speeches drawing the attention of the Senate to problems in regional Australia. We had previously discussed a number of specific regions and difficulties faced by smaller centres in rural and regional Australiaâcentres on the New England of New South Wales, in western Victoria and in the Hunter Valley. The key theme of the speeches was that the role of government had to shift from being a doer and a director to being a change leader in line with the 1994 McKinsey report. Last week I focused on some of the influences of worldwide economic forces as they are impacting on specific industries and which in turn impact on various regions. I spoke last week about the BHP shut down of the investment in most of its steel operations. I expressed my disappointment at that time that BHP was not prepared to stay in a comprehensive steel industry and that the vision of the founders of BHP, in particular Delprat and Lewis, had been lost in the passage of time.

speech.para: I rise today on a matter of great public interest in another industryâthat is, the revolution that is currently sweeping across the banking industry. Last Wednesday, Westpac announced its plan to axe a further 3,000 jobs across Australia. Since 1991, Westpac has axed some 10,000 in total and this further cut will reduce its staff by another 10 per cent. It will also close another 300 branches. According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 October this year, the latest axings from Westpac include 700 jobs in rural and regional New South Wales, 800 in Queensland, 300 in Victoria and 295 in back office jobs in a number of states. According to the report in the Australian on 14 October, Westpac will close down 200 rural branches. Of these, Westpac anticipates that some will be converted to in-store operations with the hope that staff that are shed might get a job there. According to the Newcastle Herald on 14 October, Westpac wants to achieve a national savings of $300 million.

The effect of this in my own region will be that branches with five staff or less will go in this national restructuring. The future of branches in this areaâincluding Belmont, Cardiff, Cessnock, Charlestown, Maitland, East Maitland, Hamilton, Kurri Kurri, Morisset, Newcastle, New Lambton, Raymond Terrace, Swansea, The Junction, Toronto, Wallsend and Warners Bayâis unclear. Not surprisingly, the Hunter Region Organisation of Councils has been scathing of the Westpac restructuring. The Hon. Milton Morris, former minister from 1965 to 1975 in New South Wales, had this to say:
This is an absolute kick in the teeth to country regions particularly. The rapacious attitude and the greed of the banks knows no bounds.

The Managing Director of Westpac, Mr David Morgan, says that there is still too much excess capacity in his organisation. What a change of attitude! If we go back 20 years, I remember one particular banking company screening TV ads of a man fighting his way through the bush and pushing branches out of the way, the ad carrying a caption that a certain bank had branches everywhere. That is what they were pushing at that time. This was seen as a great thing. Of course, that is no longer true.

I gained some insight into why the banks have changed their minds when I had a senior executive from one of the big four banks come to see me. He went through the way in which they decided to close their branches. It is a very simple method: they list them in order of profitabilityâmost profitable through to least profitableâand then close the least profitable. You do not have to be an expert to work out where the least profitable are; they are usually in regional and rural Australia.

talk.start.para: âBut they are still profitable.

âThey are still profitable, that is true, but they have a lower profitability, so they are shut. If the banks are making money, in my mind, there is no reason why such branches should not remain open. The combined profits of the big four banks was $9.2 billion last year. Isn't that enough? Have the banks really lost their way on the balance between the interests of their stakeholders? Let me remind the Senate who their stakeholders are. Sure, it is the shareholders; but it is also the customers, the staff and the community. The banks are now totally focused on shareholders, with very little interest in the customers, the staff or the community.

speech.para: Recently, in the launch of his book, Managing in Australia, the former Telstra CEO, Frank Blount, commented very astutely:
The role of CEO is to optimise long-term shareholder value.
It does not mean that you block out everything else like your social responsibility in communities where you work, play and invest.
You've got to balance all 4 stakeholdersâcommunity; staff; customers and shareholders.

That was said by a person who was a leader of one of the biggest organisations in Australia up until recently. In the bid to make more profit, the banks are forgetting that they are a necessary service that should be available to all Australians, including people living in rural and regional areas. The Australian public have become understandably cynical about the commitment of the banks to their area. How much profit is enough and when will banks really start giving back to the community? What they are doing instead is actually taking from the community, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

If you look at the pattern of the close down of branches, you see that in 1994 there were 6,747 bank branches in Australia, whereas in 1998 there were 5,615. Therefore, more than 1,132 branches have shut down. Since 1993, out in the rural and regional areas, there has been a 20.5 per cent reduction in the number of country branches by the big four banks. Even more shutdowns are on the horizon. Is the solution for the banks just closure and axing jobs?

There are some hopeful signs that the banks are starting to respond to community outrage. After I visited Tenterfield about a year ago I issued a press release welcoming ANZ's decision not to close any more rural branches in the next 12 months. Westpac announced on 13 October this year that by the year 2000, 200 traditional branches will be converted to in-store operations. That shows some sign of improvement, rather that the banks taking the attitude that they are just going to leave town. As I said before, 300 branches have been closed and 200 transaction centres are being opened. But they have scaled down their operations and lost a total of 100 branches.

Colonial State Bank was the leader in the establishment of in-store branches, and they should be congratulated on that. When I was in Tenterfield I did go into their corner store bank. It is set up in a corner, there are full banking facilities, with three people behind the counter, all the logos, all the stuff that is there when you normally go into a bank, and it operates out of a local business. This is great news for local business because when people come into the hardware store to do their banking, they are obviously going to do some shopping as well. So it is win-win situation all around.

But we have to recognise that what the banks are doing here is cutting their overheads considerably, and those that are keeping open the in-store banking operations should be congratulated; they manage to cut their costs but still retain their service. One would hope that the banks would adopt a socially responsible position whereby if they were the last bank to leave town, from this point on, they would actually open one of these in-store branches and leave that sort of thing behind.

What we have to realise, as we move through to using this new technology in this new information age, is that some of the technology does not replace face-to-face service. The government has introduced rural transaction services, which take up part of the slack. One would hope that this will substitute until the banks take a socially responsible position.

talk.start.para: âBreast cancer is one of the most common causes of death of Australian women. It is the most common cause of death from cancer in Australian women. On average, seven women die each day in Australia from breast cancer. In 1997, 2,602 Australian women died of breast cancer. October 25 is Australia's Breast Cancer Day. One of the great achievements of the Labor government was its initiation in 1990 of the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer. Since then more than two million mammograms have been provided free of charge to women aged 40 and over.

speech.para: The national screening program has been targeted particularly to women in the 50 to 69 years age group, those most at risk. The likelihood of developing breast cancer increases with age. Over 70 per cent of breast cancers occur in women aged over 50 years. About one in every 11 women will get breast cancer at some stage. Only about one in 10 women who get breast cancer have a family history of breast cancer. Early detection and treatment gives women the best chance of overcoming this disease.

The national screening program is already showing positive results. Although the incidence of breast cancer is increasing, the death rate is decreasing. Since 1994 the number of deaths from breast cancer have declined a little each year. In 1995 there was a four per cent fall in the mortality rate from breast cancer in Australia and in 1996 a three per cent fall.

Every year approximately 7,500 women are diagnosed as having breast cancer. BreastScreen has had a target of a national participation rate of 70 per cent for women aged from between 50 to 69 years by 1999. The national participation rate for this age group for the 24 months to 1997 was 52.2 per cent but the rate varies from state to state. In the ACT participation for this age group has now reached 68 per cent.
I wish to pay tribute to those brave women who have battled breast cancer.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âOne, whom many senators and members knew, lost her fight on 23 August this year. She was Paula O'Brien, who worked for many years as a research librarian in the Parliamentary Library, first coming to Old Parliament House in 1973. Paula was unfailingly helpful, intelligent and good natured, with a quiet sense of humour which she may have needed to cope with our sometimes near impossible demands. She kept these qualities and her thoughtfulness for others throughout her illness. During a posting to Paris with her husband from 1996 to 1998 Paula hosted a number of visiting Australian parliamentarians and their families and they will remember her cheerful willingness to share with them the things in Paris that she loved. Paula was 46.

speech.para: The cause of breast cancer is still unknown. Research into the causes, incidence and treatment of breast cancer is still of vital importance. In its 1994-95 budget the Labor government provided for the establishment of the Kathleen Cunningham Foundation for Breast Cancer Research and for the establishment of the National Health and Medical Research Council National Breast Cancer Centre, which provided $16.4 million over four years. To its credit, the present government has continued the commitment to these two bodies.

In Australia, some of the research has concerned the genes that cause cancer. Projects such as this link scientists and medical researchers across Australia. Work done at the Austin Research Institute in Melbourne and in the United States has raised hopes that a vaccine may in time be developed. Research is also under way on the possible linkage of a virus with breast cancer. Through the National Breast Cancer Centre the many groups working in research, client and service areas throughout Australia are brought together, and collaborative partnerships developed.

One of the needed areas for breast cancer research may be that of the incidence and early detection in women like Paula, younger than 50 years. Regular mammographic screening does not appear to be so useful for pre-menopausal women as the breast tissue is denser, making mammograms very difficult to read.

In recent times some criticism has been made of the attention now given to breast cancer. But this was a long neglected disease and many women died needlessly with too late diagnoses. The improved survival rate is due in large part to the awareness campaigns of the 1990s. Yet, while the incidence of deaths generally from breast cancer is falling, the potential years of life lost figure continues to rise, up from 29,420 potential years lost in 1995, to 31,418 potential years lost in 1997. The magnitude of the problem may be judged with the comparison of 5,930 potential years lost in 1997 through prostate cancer.

National data on the incidence of breast cancer in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women is still needed. It appears that the incidence of breast cancer in ATSI women is similar or slightly lower than in non-Aboriginal women. But this may be simply that there is a high rate of underreporting of cases. We don't really yet know. However, the death rate from breast cancer amongst ATSI women is slightly higher than that of non-Aboriginal women. In the two years from 1993 to 1995, 26 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women aged from 50 to 69 years had a mammogram with BreastScreen, compared with 37 per cent of non-Aboriginal women in this age group over the same period.

Access to breast screening services and to follow-up services for women diagnosed with breast cancer for ATSI women and for rural and regional women is still a major need. For these women there is a need to increase awareness about and encourage participation in screening and early detection programs. Training of ATSI health workers in this area and the development of specialised and accessible support services in rural areas should be priorities for this government.

Other priority needs identified at Australia's first national breast cancer conference for women in October last year were: more breast care nurses to follow women from diagnosis throughout treatment, ensuring that all women are provided with information at the time of diagnosis and before treatment; communication skills to be included in medical education and training; consumer representation in decision making related to breast cancer research and in the development and coordination of clinical trials; increased and continuing funding for medical, scientific and policy research; a national link for young women with breast cancer; and, finally, equitable access to clinical trials, therapies and drugs and to all support services for women with advanced breast cancer.

In closing, I would like to recognise all of the women who participated in the National Breast Cancer Network's field of women around Australia. I would also like to acknowledge the work of so many in our community and within the corporate sector who are prepared to offer their time and funds to the cause of raising awareness amongst women in this country about breast cancer. I would like to reiterate that National Breast Cancer Day on 25 October is an initiative most worthy of the support of all Australians. It is a time not only for us to remember those who have suffered from this disease, but also a time to celebrate the efforts of numerous scientists and health professionals across the country and around the world who contribute positively to breast cancer research.

talk.start.para: âTwo weeks ago a group of journalists were sharing a bowl of pasta and a plate of bruschetta in the cafe belt of Sydney, musing about the upcoming referendum with one or two of the intellectual giants of the republican debateâthe yes case. The chat was about a dilemma facing the republicans: `Why won't the women support us? Why can't the girls understand our simple premise and just say yes?' No-one really had the answer and, as the cab sav warmed up the debate, and more than a few cheeks, out came this remarkable gem from a fearless republican general: `The stupid housewives of Australia will lose us this debate. All the intelligent women know to vote yes. Why don't they?'

speech.para: Perhaps I can be of some assistance. The latest Age poll, published last weekâdespite that newspaper's clear advocacy for a yes voteâshows that female readers still remain to be convinced. While 48 per cent of men declare themselves to be republicans, only 39 per cent of women agree. So the women of Australia in their thousands are questioning this republic, and for very good reasons.

Calls to my office indicate that womenâand more than a few menâwant to know why this referendum is a priority now, why it takes precedence over all the other important community issues that we are confronting: jobs for young people, the drugs problem, crime, health and so on. They are right of courseâthere are many more important matters on the government's agenda than this costly referendum. They have also become aware of the 69 changes which will be needed to the Constitution when there have been only a baker's dozen in the last 100 years, and they want to know what that will mean. They are correct again. Even the well-known republican Thomas Keneally has described it as `the biggest structural change to our Constitution'âor, to use Lachlan Murdoch's words, voting yes would bring about `our revolution'.

Women are worried about the costs of a change. As managers of the household budget, they are financially well informed, but there is no clear answer on this question. Nobody can say with any certainty what that cost will be on top of the estimated $120 million that has already been spent so far. `What a community priority', they say, and I agree with them. Then there is the important question they raise of the role of women in the political appointment process. Once again, they are right. Despite there being the largest number of elected women in the federal parliament ever in our history, the fact is that 75 per cent of members and senators are men. And women, particularly older working women, understand the magnitude of the built-in bias against the appointment of a woman as our President. On this issue, I agree with the eminent lawyer and direct-elect republican Jocelynne Scutt, who said earlier this week:

If you have a presidential system that is controlled by the Prime Minister with the agreement of the Leader of the Opposition and then the endorsement of two thirds of the parliament, why on earth would we think that women have an equal chance of getting up under that system?
Why indeed? Dr Scutt continued:

In the end, I want a transparent system . . . the reality for me is that a transparent system does assist women . . . I want all women and men in Australia to know who the possibilities are for president, and to have a transparent system . . .

More than Dr Scutt are wise to the obstacles placed before women when it comes to being President, whether she was chosen or elected by all Australians. For while it is true that more women are being elected to the federal parliament, the fact is that 22 of them are in the Senate. This is where the shameful bias against not only women but also the rights of every state in this nation are revealed for all to see because, while the senatorsâmale and femaleârepresenting their states will have a chance to vote in the selection process now being proposed, that is where the opportunities for our state representatives end.

If in the regrettable circumstance that this flawed model was accepted by a majority of states and, even more unfortunately, if the President was to be dismissed by the Prime Minister, where do you think the senators would be when a motion supporting his decision went before the House of Representatives? Absolutely nowhere! They will not be included in the debate or in the vote. There will be no joint sitting for this motion and no representatives of the states will be allowed into the House of Representatives to debate this Prime Minister's unilateral decision. Nowhere! There will be no senatorsâmale or femaleâand no representatives of the states anywhere to be seen on the green carpet on that day. So much for states rights. As Dr Scutt may have noticedâbecause, as I have just observed, only members of the House of Representatives will vote on the dismissal motionâonly 33 women will be involved in the vote or have an opportunity to take part in the debate.

Given that women comprise 52 per cent of the population or 9,502,848 people, affirmative action as well as democracy and state rights seem to be strangely absent on this occasion. The women of Australia are awake to it and they are questioning it in droves. They know a shonky model when they see one, and they know they are looking at one with this republican model that is on offer. Informal research indicates that the largest group of women who believe that the republic may be too much change are aged between 25 and 45, have children and usually manage the finances in their homes. They are the women who are already worried about this country's priorities for their children and grandchildren: what jobs they are going to have, what their health choices will be and, perhaps most important of all, the pervasive drugs scene in this country. These are the intelligent women of Australia, and they are well aware of the murky future of the model on offer. To quote that very brave republican general at the Sydney cafe:
All the intelligent people know to vote yes, why don't the women?
I have news for that fellow: the intelligent men and women of Australia have thought very carefully about the revolution that this republican model would deliver, and they are correctly voting no.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to address two matters, the first of which relates to the outstanding achievement of Mark Occhilupo, who only a few days ago became the world professional surfing champion. I do not know Mark Occhilupo, but I have followed his career with a great deal of interest for many years. That is particularly because I am a lifelong resident of the Sutherland shire of Sydney and for many years lived in Cronulla. Of course, we in the Cronulla region not only believe but know that we have the greatest surfing beaches in Australia. Mark Occhilupo, as a very young boy, commenced his surfing career in the Cronulla region. He was quickly noticed because of his aggressive style of surfing, which led to him being nicknamed the Raging Bull. He surfed waves in Cronulla and elsewhere like no one else had done before. He quickly came to the notice of people in the surfing fraternityâhere was a young surfer with incredible talent and a great future. He was also referred to affectionately, and is still known today, as Occy.

speech.para: As I said, I did not know him and I have nothing in common with him other than that I was a goofy-footer when I tried to ride a surfboard, which is not the normal method of doing so. This, in particular, made it even more difficult for Mark to achieve success because surfing generally does not favour goofy-footers, just as golf generally does not favour left-handers. In his early years, Mark showed tremendous potential, and in his first three yearsâat the very young age of 16 and 17âhe was No. 3 and No. 4 in the world. Unfortunately, he dropped out of surfing for a number of years. His life story in that regard has been well chronicled, and I do not have to go into it. But a couple of years ago, he returned to his great love of surfing, got back into fitness, and within two years he was back and has now achieved the status of world champion. He has done that at the age of 33, which is regarded as certainly well past the normal age at which people are likely to achieve such a world championship.

I believe it is appropriate that his great achievement be recognised. I understand that it is not possible for me to do so by way of a notice of motion because of the particular rules that apply to notices of motion. I wish that were different because, if we can have receptions for our sporting teams in this building and recognise them, I would have hoped that we could also do so by way of a particular resolution of the parliament. They are the rules and I accept them, but I think it is fitting that we do recognise him. The sporting world throughout Australia, certainly the people of our area in Sydney and indeed the surfing fraternity of the world have recognised that this is a truly great achievement, demonstrating personal dedication and determination by somebody who is a great ambassador for his sport and for his country.

In my remaining time, I turn to another subject which I have spoken about on a couple of occasions in the last two weeks and which is the same matter that has just been addressed by Senator Ferrisâthat is, the forthcoming referendum on 6 November. I listened with interest to Senator Ferris's remarks. She has claimed that the proposal to have an Australian head of state is a sexist proposal, a sexist model, and she has spoken tonight about why she believes the women of Australia will not vote for this. I have to say that I have never heard such a spurious argument in my life. What could be more sexist, what could be more of an insult to the intelligence of Australian women, than to have a system as we do now, which says that the head of state of Australiaâwho is also the head of state of the United Kingdomâmust be the first born male heir of the royal family? If the first born male heir of the royal family is unable to take the crown for some particular reason, it shall then go to the next born male heir. That is why the next head of state of Australia will be Prince Charles, the eldest son of the current Queen.

If for some particular reason, as I have referred to in earlier debates, there are circumstances such as those that occurred in 1936, with the then Prince Edward, who became King Edward VIII, having to abdicate, who does the throne then extend to? It extends to the next male child. In that case it was George VI. In the case of the current royal family it would not be the next born child, Princess Anne, the female, who would take the crown; it would be Prince Andrew. Frankly, to have Senator Ferris stand up here tonight and attack the proposed republican model which would lead to an Australian head of state who could be a man or a woman, and to suggest that we should retain our current system based upon male hereditary right, where you must also be a member of the Church of Englandâ

talk.start.para: âWhat about Queen Elizabeth? We have a queen now.

âThe only reason we have a queen, as you know, is that King George VI died without having any male children. That is why the Queen is the current head of state. But if subsequent to the birth of Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret there had been a third child, a male child, he would have been the King. You know that. This puts the lie to this nonsense that is put about by Senator Ferris and others in the monarchist cause. They will stoop to the lowest level to run any nonsensical, spurious, mischievous and deliberately misleading argument to try and knock over this referendum. I believe that the intelligence of the Australian people, and the intelligence of Australian women, is far greater than Senator Ferris gives them credit for. If Senator Ferris thinks they are going to swallow that argument and swallow all of the other lies and distortions that have been put about by those supporting the monarchist cause, she should think again.

speech.para: I want to close on this note. The question that needs to be answered by the monarchistsâit has not been answered and they refuse to answer it because they know that they have no logical answerâis why it is that the United Kingdom is entitled to have its own head of state but that Australia is not. Why should we have the head of state of another country? Surely we have grown up enough. Surely we have been able to cope with change throughout this century. We have brought about a situation where we now have Australian governors-general rather than viscounts, dukes and lords from England. We have changed our legal system by abolishing appeals to the Privy Council. That did not destroy the legal system in this country. It was not a necessary change but it was one that was important symbolically and important for the total independence of this country. We have managed to change our legal system in that way and still retain our stable democracy. We can do so again with our own head of state on 6 November.

talk.start.para: âIt is a delight to be able to participate in this debate and pay a compliment to the excellent contribution of Senator Ferris in this debate. It is interesting to note that the Labor Party did not seek to match Senator Ferris's very timely and excellent remarks with a female speaker.

speech.para: On 6 November the people of Australia will be deciding not in relation to particular individuals who might be the monarch for the time being of Australia but in relation to the system. It is the system that they will be considering. Indeed, the system under which we have been governed thus far has served us very well, and I do not think anyone would seek to dispute that. So whether we have a queen or a king as head of Australia really is not an issue in this debate.

talk.start.para: âSo why not change?
âWhat is at issue is whether the proposed replacement is as good as or better than the current situation.
âSophistry.
âSilly Senator Forshaw continues to interject. I am on the record for many years now as favouring Australia becoming a republic.
âYou are a closet monarchist.
âI moved amendments to the Liberal Party state constitution in Tasmania on that very issue some four years ago, Senator Forshawâ
âWe will check that.
âJust relax over there and take your leader's adviceâtake a Bex and a cup of tea. We heard you in silence and you might pay the same courtesy to us.

speech.para: The situation is that as somebody with republican sentiment I am not going to foist upon Australia a system that I know will be worse for our country. When Malcolm Turnbullâpossibly the general Senator Ferris was referring to, but we do not knowâwas asked at a forum in Sydney recently, `Can you look me in the eye and tell me that this is the best possible republican model for Australia?' Malcolm Turnbull stuttered, stalled, stumbled and sought to evade the question because he himself knows in his heart of hearts that it is an appalling model. The instant dismissal of the President is completely unacceptable and is a significant change to our Constitution. The Prime Minister cannot sack the Governor-General in the same way. If you want proof of that, I suggest that people look at page 111 of Gough Whitlam's book The Truth of the Matter, where he confirms that very point. That is the real concern that many Australians have about the proposed model. I urge my fellow Australians, albeit that they may harbour republican sentiment, as I do, to vote no.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 25 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it correct that Centrelink staff are not required to give their full names to members of the public or clients.

(2) Does this not make an already unequal relationship even more demeaning and disempowering, given that clients have to disclose personal details while the staff member can choose to remain anonymous.

(3) After a person becomes eligible for intensive assistance: (a) how long does that person have to wait before it is provided; (b) does the waiting period vary from region to region; if so, how: (c) does it vary over time; if so, how; (d) is there any limit to the waiting period; and (e) what factors determine the length of the waiting period.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is not policy or practice for Centrelink staff to withhold their names from the public. Centrelink is committed to providing a quality service to the public. The only circumstance where a Centrelink staff member has the option of not disclosing their full name is when they have been threatened or harassed by a customer. Under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991, Centrelink has a duty of care responsibility to protect the health and safety at work of its staff. Most customers do not behave in a manner which would require staff to adopt such a means of securing their safety. However, when a staff member is threatened or harassed by a customer, the staff member may choose to use only their first name in correspondence to the particular customer who has made a threat.

(2) Centrelink takes its responsibilities to both customers and staff seriously and does not believe that the protection of a staff member from a threatening and potentially unsafe situation, as outlined above, to be demeaning and disempowering for the customer.

(3) (a)The period between the time a job seeker becomes eligible for Intensive Assistance and their referral to a Job Network member depends on the number of job seekers who have previously been assessed as eligible and the number of positions available with local Job Network members.
As job seekers are placed in employment, or exit Intensive Assistance after completing their placement with a Job Network member, new job seekers are referred to these members.
Referrals occur in chronological order of the date job seekers are assessed as eligible for this assistance.

(b) Yes. It varies according to the number of Intensive Assistance places available and the rate at which job seekers leave Intensive Assistance either for work or because their placement has finished. In areas with a more active labour market, or more successful Job Network members, this turnover will be quicker and waiting times shorter.
It also depends on the number of eligible job seekers within a particular area. In areas where there are comparatively more eligible job seekers, the waiting time for referral could be longer.

(c) Yes it can. If the employment within a particular area increases and more job seekers in Intensive Assistance return to work, more vacancies are created with the Job Network members. Also, job seekers awaiting placement with a member may find work prior to referral and the waiting times in that area can decrease.

If there is a downturn in employment, and more job seekers are identified who are eligible for Intensive Assistance, the number of job seekers leaving Intensive Assistance to return to work may reduce and waiting times may increase.

(d) There is no maximum waiting time for referral to Intensive Assistance. However, each Intensive Assistance placement lasts for 12 to 18 months (with a possible extension of up to 6 months if the Job Network member believes an employment outcome is likely). As job seekers complete their Intensive Assistance placement or leave for other reasons such as employment, other job seekers are referred.
This ensures that there is a turnover of job seekers through Intensive Assistance giving each eligible job seeker a chance to participate.

(e) Waiting times are determined by the number of Intensive Assistance positions available in a particular area, the number of job seekers who have been previously assessed as eligible, but are still waiting referral, and the number of job seekers leaving Intensive Assistance because of employment or other reasons (like completion of placement).

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Assistance Program: Area Consultative Committees
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1370)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 August 1999:

question.para: (1) When was each Area Consultative Committee (ACC) established as part of the Regional Assistance Program.
(2) (a) What was the location of each ACC; and (b) what federal electorates were incorporated in the area covered by each ACC.

(3) Has the area covered by each ACC varied since its establishment; if so: (a) how has the region varied; (b) what was the basis of each variation; and (c) when were the changed boundaries communicated to the department.
(4) (a) What was the membership of each ACC at the time of its establishment; and (b) what changes to the membership of each ACC has occurred since it was first established.

(5) What process was followed in the selection of people to be appointed to each ACC; in each case; (a) who was consulted as part of that selection process; and (b) who made the final decision on the membership of each ACC.
(6) (a) Who was appointed as the chair of each ACC at the time of its establishment; and (b) what changes to the chair of each ACC have occurred since it was first established.

(7) What process was followed in the selection of people to be appointed to chair each ACC and in each case: (a) who was consulted as part of that selection process; and (b) who made the final decision on the chair of each ACC.
(8) (a) What funding was provided to each ACC in the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years; and (b) how much of that funding allocation was expended by each ACC in each financial year.

(9) (a) How much of that funding was reallocated between ACCs in each financial year; (b) which ACCs received additional funding; and (c) what was the amount of additional funding received by each ACC as a result of the above re-allocation.

(10) Was funding for any ACC supplemented from consolidated revenue or from another program in either of the above financial years; if so (a) which ACCs received additional funding ; (b) how much additional funding was provided; (c) when was the additional funding sought; (d) when was the request met; and (e) who approved the additional money.
(11) Where additional funding was provided at the request of the ACC: (a) how was the additional funding used; and (b) was all of the additional funding expended.

(12) If additional funding provided to an ACC in the above financial years was not requested by the ACC: (a) who requested the funding; (b) what was the basis for the request; and (c) who approved the request.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) ACCs were not established as a part of the RAP. ACCs were established in 1994. RAP commenced on 1 July 1997. From that date ACCs were given a supporting role in relation to the development and endorsement of proposals for RAP funding.
(2) A copy of the responses to (a) and (b) is being separately supplied to the honourable senator (a copy is also held in the Senate Table Office).

(3) Responses to (a) (b) and (c) are contained in the table provided for (2) above. I am advised by my department that while dates have been provided where possible in relation to changes in ACC areas, such amendments were most often addressed by consultation over a period of time between the relevant ACC(s) and the department.

(4) (a) and (b) I am advised by my department that this information is not readily available. I am also advised that the sum of the resources required to answer this question in its entirety would represent an unwarranted diversion of the resources of the Department and there could be no guarantee that the information finally identified would be comprehensive.

(5) The Secretary of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has the authority to appoint members of ACCs. However, in practice, Chairs of each ACC select members in accordance with the requirements of their rules of incorporation under State law. (a) This is at the discretion of the Chair of the ACC. However, it is expected that State offices of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business be consulted in this process. To assist in identifying suitable members, the Hon Tony Abbott MP, Minister for Employment Services, wrote to all Government members and to the Hon Martin Ferguson MP as spokesperson for the Federal Opposition, inviting them to forward to the department the names of any potential appointees to ACCs.
(b) The Chair, or the membership, depending on the rules of incorporation for each ACC under State law.

(6) (a) and (b) A table containing the information is being separately supplied to the honourable senator (a copy is also held in the Senate Table Office). I am advised by my department that dates in relation to the terms of each Chair have been provided wherever historical records have permitted.

(7) I am advised by my department that details of the process of the appointment of individual Chairs to each ACC prior to October 1998 are not readily available. I am also advised that the sum of the resources required to answer this question in its entirety would represent an unwarranted diversion of the resources of the Department and there could be no guarantee that the final information obtained would be comprehensive. Since the transfer of responsibility for ACCs to my department in October 1998, the procedure for the appointment of Chairs is for the Secretary of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business to appoint Chairs to ACCs following the provision of nominees from state managers, the outgoing Chair or ACC members.

(a) To identify nominees, the Secretary and State Managers may consult the outgoing Chair, existing members of ACCs, local community leaders, the register maintained by the Office of the Status of Women and other government bodies as considered appropriate or desirable. The Secretary may also consult with Ministers' offices.
(b) The Secretary of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.

(8) I am advised by my department that the information for the financial year 1997-98 is not readily available. I am also advised that the sum of the resources required to answer this question in its entirety would represent an unwarranted diversion of the resources of the Department. A table containing the information based on State office records for (a) & (b) for 1998-99 is being separately supplied to the honourable senator (a copy is also held in the Senate Table Office).

(9) (a) (b) and (c). I am advised by my department that prior to the transfer of responsibility for ACCs to my department in October 1998, there was no formal process for the re-allocation of funds between ACCs. At the local level some re-allocation may have occurred due to under-expenditure or on a needs basis. However, I am advised that details on any re-allocations that may have taken place are not readily available. The new guidelines issued by my department on 18 July 1999 provide for the department to re-allocate unspent funds at its discretion.
(10) I am advised by my department that no ACC was supplemented from consolidated revenue or another program for either of the financial years.
(11) Not applicable.
(12) Not applicable.

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Assistance Program: Area Consultative Committee Plans
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1372)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has each Area Consultative Committee (ACC) formed through the Regional Assistance Program (RAP) lodged both a Strategic Regional Plan (SRP) and an Annual Business Plan (ABP); if so, when was each SRP and ABP completed by each ACC.
(2) Must each SRP and ABP be approved by the department; if so: (a) have all the above plans been approved; and (b) when was each plan approved.
(3) If some ACCs have not yet completed an SRP or an ABP, which ACCs have failed to complete these plans.
(4) Which ACCs were provided with funding through the RAP prior to the lodgement and approval of an SRP and an ABP.

(5) In each case: (a) how much funding was provided; (b) when was the funding provided; (c) who approved the funding; and (d) how long after funding was allocated did each ACC complete an SRP and an ABP.

(6) (a) How many proposals for assistance through the RAP were lodged by ACCs that had not lodged an SRP or an ABP; (b) how many of these proposals were approved by a state office of the department; and (c) how many proposals were approved by the national office.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) As stated in my response to Question 1370, ACCs were not formed through RAP. I am advised by my department that all Strategic Regional Plans for 1998 + 2000 were lodged by 30 September 1998. At the time of the preparation of this response, most Annual Business Plans (ABPs) for 1999/2000 have also been lodged. Usually, ABPs are expected to be finalised in the quarter preceding the commencement of the financial year. However, because new guidelines were being developed the lodgement date was extended to end September 1999.
(2) No. However, it is expected that ACCs will consult with the State offices of my department in the development of their plans; (a) not applicable (b) not applicable.
(3) None.

(4) ACCs do not generally receive funding under RAP. The ACC role is to facilitate and endorse applications for funds under RAP from project proponents in their region. ACCs receive separate allocations to cover the operational costs of ACCs. All ACCs are allocated a notional amount of base funding which is not contingent on the development of plans. Funding additional to the base is dependent on the development of the plans. My department advises that all ACCs have developed a Strategic Regional Plan and have either lodged or are soon to lodge an Annual Business Plan.
(5) Not applicable.
(6) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 August 1999:

question.para: (1) How many proponents of projects approved for funding in the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years through the Regional Assistance Program (RAP) were for non-profit organisations.

(2) Where the successful applicant was a normal commercial enterprise seeking to generate a financial return: (a) what was the name of each applicant; (b) what was the nature of each project; (c) how much funding through the RAP was sought; (d) when was each application lodged; and (e) when was the application approved.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Busi ness has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am advised by my department based on available historical data, that all proponents of approved projects, a total of 949 to date, were non-profit.
